Few books have given me the sense of satisfaction as profound as this one. I admit that not the whole book was a breeze to read. There are certain chapters which require you to discipline yourself to read through, but considering that the subject matter itself is so academic I really have to admire the authors ability to have made it so approachable even to a layman. Majority of the chapters in the book are an absolute treat to read - especially the first four and the last three. Pinker does an excellent job at keeping the reader engaged and at the same time put forward some really interesting propositions. This book is dense with information and you will walk away as a much more knowledgeable person at the end of it than you were when you started, and this is something you can hardly say for most of the books out there. More than anything the book tries to explains the complexities of language generation in our mind, puts forth extremely interesting theories backed by studies, and introduces us to cognitive psychology and linguistics in one fell swoop. It mainly tries to put forth the idea that language is in fact an innate Instinct that humans possess and have developed as part of evolution - much like breathing. There are certain segments that I absolutely loved. Note able among those would be how Pinker debunks popular linguistic myths like the Hopi having no concept of time, the staggering number of words that Eskimos have for snow and so many more - and he does it with such nonchalance. I especially loved the theory that tries to explain why the left part of our brain controls the right part of our body and vice versa. Invertebrates don't show this assymetry, so the closest theory that comes to explaining this is that, some organism which existed at the mid stage between invertebrates and vertebrates, rotated it's head by 180 degrees! The fact that the placement of primary nueral connections and the heart coincides with this change is something staggering! The theory itself is not proven, and it doesn't explain why anyone would ever do a 180 degree turn, but as a mental exercise that is something really interesting.It talks about how children are grammar geniuses and how our ability to learn a new languages dimishes as we grow through adulthood - and why (again this is another explanation I loved - it is simply a cost benefit that evolution figured out, certain skills are more valuable when young, and can be enhanced in childhood at the cost of its continued reduction over time into old age; this is true for most human traits), it explains how all languages in the world are similar after all, and how a persons ability to think complex thoughts is in no way governed by what language he speaks - something a lot of us seem to misunderstand. The book is filled with such explanations, questions, counter questions and insights. This book will make you ever more hungry for knowledge and that is why I would highly recommend it.

An erudite but sharply-written (read, eminently readable) look at the nexus of language forms and neural responses, along with a nicely acidic putdown of self-styled language experts who pontificate - often wrongly - about usage. It was written in 1994 and apparently served as a highly influential state-of-the-discipline on publication. Certainly I have seen more than one book quoting Pinker's arguments regarding the innate 'grammar gene' (a term so often misused in the media since that time) which children are born with. Despite this, even today so-called 'common sense' tends to repeat the opposite line - that the little tykes simply copy examples from their surroundings. Now that I have an almost 3 year old tyke, right in the language learning 'sweet spot', I can vouch for the argument given here, because she 'invents' logical, regular verb forms for irregular verbs which she certainly never heard before and her placement of whole phrases is unerringly accurate, with only the occasional kiddy vowels or tripped-over syllables to let you know the speaker's age for sure.The success of Pinker's work lies in hauling us directly into this nexus between different fields without dumbing-down or sensationalising. He attacks often (and often wittily) but also, like a good scientist, proffers his own assumptions and caveats for scrutiny. Nothing is set in stone but the alternatives to Pinker's arguments come to seem increasingly implausible. For example, those who throw their hands up at the tortuous path of the language instinct's evolution and run back to creationism just need to run their own logic by themselves: if there was a 'divine' intervention, then why was language not fully formed from the outset? Why did language take so long to get where it has got and why did it have to take the tortuous route it took with all the different versions and hot wired foibles? It is most clearly not the work of a master plan. It is more plausibly a super skill gained partly by chance and partly by necessity, developed in ways that have a common thread (or grammar) in many different parts of the world, homogenised in some by history and divided in others by geology or serendipity. The Earth is more or less the same: a lucky position vis-a-vis the Sun, a climate that allowed life as we know it to sing its particular song.Throughout this book there's a thrill in feeling informed, in attacking the 'supercilious pundits' (and some are very much so) with weapons bigger than their own and in boning up on some neuroscience to focus on the underlying mechanics of this language instinct.
Interesting though I remain skeptical on many of Pinker's conclusions.

Reviewed as part of my 100 books challenge: http://jimmylongley.com/blog/books/Run-on Sentence SummaryA fun, accessible, and thorough introduction to linguistics.ImpressionsLinguistics is of those fields that everyone is naturally curious about. Pinker takes that itch and thoroughly scratches it. He covers lots of ground, such as how languages evolve, how language acquisition happens, how language and thought relate, and the fundamental properties of all language.He answers many questions I’ve wondered about forever. For example, do we think in language? No, of course not, otherwise how could languages evolve? Language is necessarily ambiguous for brevity and therefore can't be used for common sense reasoning. For example, which would be the newspaper headline, “Man bites dog” or “Dog bites man”? By the way, this context-dependence is called “deixis” and is one of the main reasons natural language processing by computers is so difficult.Does our mother tongue fundamentally shape the ways we can think? This is a common misconception, and there is no scientific evidence that it is true. You may have heard about how inuits have hundreds of words for snow, but it is a conventional absurdity.My favorite fun fact was about William the Conqueror. When he invaded England in 1066, he brought with him the norman dialect of french to serve as the language of the ruling classes. Words naturally seeped into English, giving us many idiosyncratic grammar rules such as “electric” -> “electricity”. The latinate segment of English, due to its long words and history of formality, is responsible for what we see as stuffy language. For example: “The adolescents who had effectuated forcible entry into the domicile were apprehended,” instead of the anglo-saxon, “We caught the kids who broke into the house”Final ThoughtsPinker’s style is witty and polished, and he packs a ton of information into a concise and addicting book. This is one of my favorite pop science books ever. I can’t wait to move on to his style guide, "The Sense of Style."Favorite Quote“The English language is a rich verbal tapestry woven together from the tongues of the Greeks, the Latins, the Angles, the Klaxtons, the Celtics, and many more other ancient peoples, all of whom had severe drinking problems.”

I started this book hoping to get the basics of linguistics for one of my projects. I am very glad I went on with this book and not Chomsky’s Syntactic Structures (Read few pages and couldn’t understand anything). This book was like a quick crash course on linguistics. While most of his work is build on Noam Chomsky’s Universal Grammar, Steven Pinker, professor of psychology at Harvard, differs from Chomsky's theory a lot. Pinker talks about everything from the difference between vowels and consonants, the grammar in black vernacular English and Pidgins, Morphology and Phonology. Why children of migrated parents don’t get their parent’s accent? Why there is not a significant difference in language abilities in the different part of the world while the culture changes drastically? etc.. In short, he says humans are born with language skill, and it's not something that we acquire after we are born (Nature vs. Nurture). Apparently, this is just one school of thought in linguistics (Refer Linguistic Wars).Steven Pinker along with Neil deGrasse Tyson and few other are notable scientists who want to take science to the common man. It is a very appreciable and noble work especially in the times when half of the North America doesn’t believe in global warming. The problem though is the language and scientific vocabulary they use. It is understandable that the language should not be brought down so much that it loses its essence. But a bit more effort to communicate some basic stuff would have made it more enjoyable and at the same time informative for me. As it stands, the book is very informative but not easily enjoyable. But it should be mentioned that the author has put visible efforts in making it more understandable like have a glossary for all the linguistic terms. Maybe what Steven Levitt did with Freakonomics series by joining hands with a writer or as simple as having more (at least some) subtitles in 50-page chapter putting everything in context might help.On the whole, the book is condensed. The first half of the book is easily readable compared to the other half. Maybe the information that I was looking for were in the there. Despite all my rantings on the writing (or my inability to understand the text), I would recommend it to anybody interested in linguistics or just curious about how language works.

If your not sure about this book. Just pick it up in the bookstore and turn to page 355. If find the chart there terribly amusing then go ahead and buy it. If not you might want to move on.Pinker has obviously thought about this, a lot....people simply assume that words determine thoughts...Sometimes it is not easy to find any words that properly convey a thought. When we hear or read, we usually remember the gist, not the exact words, so there has to be such a thing as a gist this is not the same as a bunch of words....if there can be two thoughts corresponding to one word, thoughts can't be words.Our sixth sense may perceive speech as a language, not as sound, but it is a sense, something that connects us to the world, and not just a form of suggestibility.When a series of facts comes in succession, as in a dialogue or text, the language must be structured so that the listener can place each face into an existing framework.This mirrors my thoughts exactly- not only for words but for knowledge in general....there is a specific syndrome called Pure Word Deafness that is exactly what it sounds like: the patients can read and speak, and can recognize environmental sounds ... but cannot recognize spoken words; words are meaningless...Oh boy! This is sooo me! Often I have to visualize the written words before I can understand what was said.Great advice Pinker received from one of his editors-Think of your readers as your college roommates: people who are as smart and intellectually curious as you...I agreed with most of his conclusions but he lost me at;"The linguistic clumsiness of [age] might be the price we pay for the linguistic genius we displayed as babies"I just don't see why it has to be a zero-sum game.It's funny that the next book I read was Paul Allen's biography. At the end he talks about how incredibly difficult it is to catalog and index vast amounts of information. Pinker was even mentioned by name! Certainly those two geniuses could pool their knowledge and come up with an algorithm based on Pinker's understanding of language to file and organize all that is known on a subject.

A overview of linguistic theory regarding the structure of languages, universal commonalities between languages, language disorders, and how these come together to give scientists a picture of how the brain processes language. The central argument is that despite the diversity of languages across history, the brain must have certain biologically rooted, innate language processing systems. I found the evidence on the balance to be fairly convincing, although the book's chapters vary quite a bit in how convincing they were. Without attributing language function to specific brain structure, it is difficult to explain how children pick up languages so quickly, or the pidgin-creole evolution of languages, or some of the disorders encountered in the book. But I don't know that many people would disagree with this point, and so the book is less argument here than a description of the state of science at the time of its writing (1994). With regard to language universals, I found the book to be much less compelling. For instance, I failed to see the significance of the "mice-eater"/"rat-eater" issue or "flew"/"flied", two examples Pinker used to argue that people are systematic about sentence and word construction. Doesn't the presence of irregular verbs at all fly against this anyway? While there are systematic rules within a language I don't see any universals here and I don't see how this necessarily points to an instinct above and beyond general flexible grammar processing (in this language the verbs go here, etc.). Pinker writes in a friendly, somewhat folksy manner, sprinkling his writing with jokes and humorous anecdotes, and when he is debunking myths about language he is at his most entertaining. The Whorf theory (Eskimos having many words for snow) is really convincingly trashed, and the useless deprecations by snooty grammarians about the decline of writing standards and proper English and civilization in general are themselves properly counter-deprecated by Pinker. A decent book, one that will get me to read more on linguistics at some point, but not one that blew me away.

This was probably a good book, but it was too much of a slog for me to appreciate. It raises thought-provoking questions, proposes equally interesting answers, contains lots of little historical tidbits, and has moments of fun wordplay, but the sum is somehow less than all of these parts.This is the second time I've read a linguistics book for a general audience, and I am again struck by how much some linguists seem to want to be mathematicians. Pinker makes tangential reference to an impressive number of technical subfields of mathematics, computer science, and logic, but some of his (or his camp's; I'm unclear on that distinction) inferences about how the mind creates and understands language are less than compelling. There are a number of times that (my understanding of) his argument boils down to "we can only think of two explanations for how this would work, empirical evidence eliminates one, so the other has to be true." There is also an implicit assumption that whatever computational ability underpins the brain in general and language in particular has a to be consistent, contradiction-free, logical system. One might certainly wish that's the case, but it is not obvious to me at all that this must be so, and there was never any attempt to justify that assumption.Some quick notes... The empirical observations about how and when children develop language was very interesting. I really disliked just about every section that discussed technical details of proposed grammars: they were never precise enough to be rigorous (or maybe I was unwilling to read carefully enough to see the rigor), but you still had to slog through far too much technical jargon to make for an interesting read; this was somehow the worst of both worlds. The description of the historical evolution of language families was fascinating, and Pinker was very upfront about how much conjecture was in that narrative. The language mavens chapter was great; it was entertaining and he made a compelling point about how we judge people by the language/dialects they use.my favorite quote: "Mental flexibility confines children; innate constraints set them free."

This book is great popular science writing - it strikes the perfect balance between including enough details that you actually learn something but not so many that it turns into just a bad textbook. His writing style is very jovial, enthusiastic, and readable though also precise enough to convey complex ideas clearly.Pinker wants to make an argument for language acquisition being something innate (an "instinct", as the title implies) as opposed to a completely social construct that we use our general intelligence to pick up. By examining many different aspects of language as well as how language is acquired in the first years of life (his specialty as a researcher), he makes a convincing argument. However I want to point out two short-comings of his approach. First, all of this theory of language is based on the ideas of Chomsky's school of linguistics and cognitive science. While Chomsky should definitely be credited as the first person to make a serious and compelling case for how language could be innate, his proposed theory for how language is organized at the cognitive level is not the only one out there. It would have been for for Pinker to explore, at least briefly, some of the alternative models. Second, Pinker's final chapter musing about what other cognitive abilities of humans that we usually think of as "learned" might also come from an innate cognitive faculty is highly speculative. There is absolutely nothing wrong with this kind of speculation, but as an authority on the subject, Pinker has some obligation to clearly inform the reader just how speculative these ideas are. I think he could have been much more clear about this.Criticisms aside, language is a fascinating phenomenon - it's the reason I chose my own direction for my doctoral studies! This book is an excellent introduction to many truly fascinating ideas about the complex structures and rules that we find in human languages. Everyone uses language, so I can't imagine anyone who would not find something in this book that is interesting to them.

It's a great introduction a the world of linguistics, and cognitive psychology, something I've never come across before.Pinker is an award winning author, specializing in experimental "psycholinguistics"; and the Language Instinct was his first popular science book. Although it was published in 1994, most of it is still relevant (at least to me, as this subject matter is entirely new). (The new 2007 edition seems to updated, but I haven't read that edition)The Language Instinct wonderfully combines cognitive sciences, behavioral genetics and evolutionary biology to make a case that language is not a complete human construct like say metal-working and pottery, but something innate (still affected by the environment though). There are cultures out there with no iron but none without a language. And there is no "bad language", all languages in the world follow their rules rigourously, even such derided ones like "black vernacular" and "teen-speak" according to Pinker. Although I'm no expert, I was convinced with Pinker's case for a "Universal Grammar". And although Pinker is only rehashing Noam Chomsky's work here, he digresses from Chomsky when he states that language is a product of natural selection (although he doesn't spend too much time on this at all).The book really shines because of Pinker's witty and erudite writing. He's always engaging and does a really great job lightening the mood every now and then with hilarious pop-culture references when the going gets tough. And boy are some sections tough to get through. Believe me when I tried really hard, but I simply had to skip some sections, maybe I'll re-read them in a couple of years. Special mention for the amazing excerpts, newspaper headlines, and comic reproductions, Pinker definitely knows how to pick them!Recommended to everyone with an interest in language, and how it affects our minds.

A fairly complex book that I would have to read several times to internalize all it offers. It is a bit too analytical for my taste, but I did learn some worthwhile points. Language is a uniquely human experience (not earth-shattering news, but no other animal has any capacity for language even remotely close to ours - something Steven Pinker enjoys pointing out as he repeatedly debunks relevant animal studies). Language is much more sophisticated in its make up (grammar, syntax, morphology, vocabulary...), in its constant evolution from generation to generation, in its innate relationship between mind, concept, sound, and transmission; and, thus, how it is learned. As (overly) thorough as always Pinker challenges conventional thought and education about language and introduces concepts of linguistics, psychoanalysis, neurology, and social science to make his various points. My biggest take-aways (among dozens offered) are: we are all born ready-wired to learn languages, but the ability to learn / speak different languages fluently rapidly deteriorates as soon as we are physically matured; languages are in constant flux as they are passed from generation to generation - as each generation actively refines & remodels what they receive in words, conventions and rules, then successively passes on minor changes (usually in more logical and simpler patterns) and introduces new words that capture old and new concepts more accurately or in usefully new nuances. What often passes as ignorance of grammar or spelling or syntax are actually modifications purposefully introduced to ease communication and improve understanding. Along the journey of this book I learned a lot more about why English is constructed as it is, why changes occurred in English over the past millennium, why it is progressively difficult to learn new languages as one ages, why and how languages continue to evolve, and why language is so uniquely human.

Pinker makes a very strong case in this book that there are common grammatical structures underlying all languages. This he refers to Chomsky (as he should), but he also develops Chomsky's idea of a universal language, but not simply stopping at looking at different languages, but instead Pinker proposes that this similarity in how languages work reflects a similarity in how the human mind works. In other words, how humans handle language, and the fact that it is made so similar (with a few parameters that changes such as word order and so on) points to a language instinct according to Pinker. Whether to call it an "instinct" or not, I think Pinker makes a good case for his argument that there is a propensity in the brain to deal with and learn language. This propensity is found in all humans in all cultures. This leads Pinker to argue against the thought that language controls thinking, rather language is an expression of thinking. I am not completely sure if Pinker makes a correct interpretation of, for example, Wittgenstein on this. I haven't made any serious studies to do prove this, but my sense is that Pinker simplifies parts of that tradition of philosophy that include Derrida, Barthes, Foucault(?).Nonetheless, this is a very readable book and it clarifies many things about language. Pinker feels fairly level headed and gentle in this book (in comparison to The Better Angels...) and he doesn't seem to have a many bones to pick just yet.What this book says about human nature and mind, I have to think about further (and it is also what I will deal with in my PhD), but I think a general question is how exactly one is to move on from the cultural examples that Pinker gives about human universals to the psychology of the human. Pinker does so by giving certain examples and criteria. I have to read them again and more carefully to see if I am really convinced.

it's hard to say what possessed me to read this book now of all times. some people will know that i've read most of ray jackendoff's Patterns in the Mind, which covers a lot of the same ground, and i've also taken/audited courses on semantic/syntactic theory with ray, so why read pinker?while confirming a lot of things any casual student of cognitive/psycho-linguistics will already know by now, pinker is still definitely worth reading, and in this book he's at his finest. he explains the basic ideas with simplicity and grace, in a way that won't be tedious even when the general concepts are familiar (though real linguists might be bored). and of course, this is pop science, so pinker steps back to capture the big picture now and again, tying together the strands of current research (c. 1995) into a coherent picture of mind, brain, language, and evolution.i'd have to say that the most valuable thing i gained from reading pinker was the way he adeptly handled the most contentious issues in this field. he makes a clear case for the core of chomskyan theory, without hesitating to draw lines where chomsky is wrong. he engages with some of the prevalent speculation about language evolution, challenging a number of widely-held beliefs. he takes a stand against the desire to find human-like language in other animals, noting that 1) it's just not there and 2) to insist that we need to find human language in order to elevate other animals to our stature is chauvinistic in the extreme.basically, i'm sorry i didn't read this book in fall of 2004, when i first started thinking seriously about these issues and could have gained the most from it. but i have no regrets at all about reading it now.

After a slow start, this book comes alive mid-way through when Pinker moves beyond the universal syntax of all languages to talk about the innate language abilities we are born with and how language, speech and hearing function within the brain. This book is rich with anecdotes and interesting facts. For instance no tribe has been discovered in modern times that didn't have a developed language equal in complexity to our so-called modern languages. Or, if a person is only exposed to language after the age of 6, he will never be able to master it (or any other language). Whereas a child can master multiple languages before the age of 6 (there appears to be no discernible limit as to the number of languages a child can master). Or, that thought is indeed possible without language - a fact debated by many philosophers but conclusively answered by Pinker. I also appreciated his outright dismissal of so-called "grammar experts" who preach that phrases like "Me and John,..." and the splitting of infinitives are incorrect usages to be avoided at all times. In actual fact deeper structural analysis shows that these rules are often false and "developed" by academics trying to complicate language for reasons other than communication. Lastly, I appreciated Pinker's defense of quirky spelling in the English language which certainly gave me some pause for thought.This is a long, deep read but fascinating if you have an interest in language and how the brain works. Behind only Noam Chompsky, Pinker is probably the leading thinker in this area at present (and a great deal more interesting to read!) I read this just before starting to learn Spanish as an adult this year and have really appreciated the deeper understanding it has given me on a) the process of learning a language and b) the inherent structure of any human language.

I don't often read something that actually changes the way I understand my world. I've been aware of Noam Chomsky's name and have vaguely associated it with a poorly understood and not-at-all-subscribed-to-by-me notion of an innate "universal grammar" for a long time. I was one of the kind of people discussed in this book, who believe that thought itself depends on language. I subscribed to what Pinker calls "The Standard Social Science Model" of absolute cultural relativism. While already a "descriptivist" with regard to the immutable purity of Standard Written English, I did believe that the bugbears of the style manuals actually contributed something to clarity and precision.Color me converted. Pinker illustrates how the emerging experimental field of cognitive science has utterly borne out Chomsky's theories. We don't teach children language. They teach themselves, or, rather, they learn how to fit the particularities of a specific learned language into pre-existing intuitive tree-like schemata for imposing and communicating cognitive order with respect to actions, actors, and the acted upon. Though they are incompetent in every other way, Pinker convincingly demonstrates that human toddlers undergoing what he calls the "grammar explosion" are linguistic geniuses. As he shows, the complex grammatical reasoning of which a two-and-a-half-year-old is capable is nothing short of breathtaking.In addition to a mind-blowing, sound-as-brickwork argument and elegant yet pointedly unpretentious style, The Language Instinct is replete with astonishing facts. I've subjected everyone I know to an endless stream of Pinker tidbits, and I've gleefully read excerpts from his screed against "language mavens" , in particular his defense of her bete noire, "I could care less," to my occasionally pedantic editor fiancee.I can't recommend this enough.

This is a must-read for anyone interested in how language works. As the title would indicate, Pinker argues that language is an instinct and that our brains come pre-programmed with a Universal Grammar and an innate capacity to fill in the blanks with the specific grammatical rules and vocabulary we hear people use around us. He also describes the basics of the modern science of language developed by Noam Chomsky and his followers, and although this section is a little technical, it is well worth reading, and Pinker adds enough humor to make it an enjoyable read.The highlight of the book, I believe, is the chapter called "The Language Mavens," in which he argues that many of the grammatical "rules" we are familiar with are actually based on ignorance of how language works. For example, two of the great "rules" we are always told about is to not split infinitives (see what I did there?) and to avoid ending a sentence with a preposition. Both of these grammatical rules are foreign to English. They started because a lot of English speakers considered Latin to be the paragon of logical consistency, and so they applied many of the rules from Latin to the much different grammar of English. Both of these "errors" are impossible in Latin, and therefore these early language mavens declared that they should be avoided by English speakers. Another error that he says is no error at all is "He took Alice and I to the airport" or other constructions of that form. This is no error because the object of the verb is not "Alice" and "I", but "Alice and I", and it is unnecessary to inflect both nouns within the phrase. This is an excellent book, and I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to know a little bit more about how language works.

This should be said right now: I love language. I love the how it shapes how we think about issues, how it evolves alongside us, and how it can unify humanity and section them at the same time. Steven Pinker took this to a new level in The Language Instinct, and it was excellent. He touched many subjects and really delved into how our mind as a computational system can process language, acquires it, and how we are able to communicating ideas. That being expressed, Pinker goes a bit too much in detail about these processes for me at times. This is a subject I'm very passionate about and interested in, but I find that I'd often be flipping through a section to see how many pages there were left in it. I felt like he continually hit the same points over and over again, and then would write for another twenty pages about the subject. Don't get me wrong- I love this book, I just think Pinker may have underestimated his audience's ability to comprehend something without explaining every minute detail. I'd recommend The Language Instinct to anyone who is already interested in language and linguistics, and has done some reading before hand. I would also not recommend it for casual reading, but more as a leisure book that you pick up from time to time. It can get mind numbing and dense. Also: it was written in the 90s, and some of his attempts at reference to pop culture and tech are no longer relevant, which may turn away younger readers. Overall, it is a great book, though, and people should read it, because it will incite a great curiosity in you. Here's a link to Pinker's website, if you wish to learn more about his work at Harvard or MIT, or his other works. Pinker's Website

It only took a couple pages to realize that I might be in way over my head with this one. But wanting to know more about linguistics and with a recommendation by Chomsky on the cover, I thought this book to be as good a place as any to get some perspective on what linguists have to say about language.I speak several languages, and unfortunately, I never bothered with the grammatical rules behind any of them. As such, I have only vague ideas of what “present perfect” or “subjunctives” or any of that stuff is. I don’t understand how the languages I speak are arranged, I just speak them. But unfortunately, large parts of this book are devoted to picking apart how sentences are arranged and organized and I couldn’t help but glaze over these parts. It was just too exhausting.There are several references to Chomsky’s work in this book and Pinker takes plenty of time discussing them. I’m pretty sure it takes up most of the book. But anyhow, the parts of the book I especially liked were Pinker’s argument that language is just a limited software we use to communicate what the hardware (the brain) is thinking. Some languages are better at translating mentalese than others. From babyhood we are already speaking a universal mental language “mentalese” and as we grow we are somehow programmed to pick up the patterns and rules through the noisy complexity learning how to use words to convey our thoughts. We pick up the patterns AND the exceptions. It’s all genetically built in, apparently. Oh and practice at an early age is essential as we lose this skill when we get older. Like I said, I was in over my head for this one, and what I understood I really enjoyed. I just might reread this book someday and maybe absorb what I had missed.

Enjoyable view of the workings of the brain from the point of view of language. I don't know if "I really liked" but it's worth the time just taking in a bit of lucid discussion about some pretty technical stuff (fortunately, stuff Pinker conveys well). You'd better like language and or if you have a problem with natural selection, this highly readable text will be a source of angst or a snooze. The text also requires attention. Given the nature of this book, for eaxample, the author has to present incorrect and "just off center" phrases to demonstrate and contrast certain language principles. And you'll find that you have to periodically re-read some sentences and phrases. Pinker provides more than adequate spacing between episodes of re-reading to prevent the episodes from becoming an annoyance. On the other hand, I noted a couple of editing errors that I otherwise might have missed - I read the paperback version. I'm not such a careful reader, but I do know these were errors because I had to stop and write out Pinker's text (an exercise I never do). When you read the book you'll see why I had to resort to writing out these two or three errant sentences to see if they were wrong. Pinker makes an arguement in his languauge mavens chapter that strikes me as mental gymnastics that defy his premise (humans are hard wired to communicate) - it concerns how a maven criticizes saying, "Give Al Gore and I your .... ", but Pinker backs into a logic-ladened gynastic/arguement rendering the phrase correct/acceptable. Dude, it's, "Give Al Gore and me ...." (Always, period)But I enjoyed your book.

the aspects of this book that detail language is excellent. the evolutionary tie-ins are stretches that are best-guesses but far from experientially proven connections. so if you love language, you will indeed enjoy this book. but a cautionary word: don't forget those critical reading skills so you don't swallow the long-stretch evolutionary wishing-is-believing ... in neuroscience and technology, the more the scientists find out, the more questions are raised. so the more they know, the more they know they don't know. so beware of firm statements of evolution when it comes to the language instinct. we wouldn't want to close out any possibilities or discoveries. the sheer depth (literally) of the process does not easily yield its methods and whereas pinker does indeed outline the difficulties of studying the deep process of language, he seems to disregard this reality as he jumps on the evolutionary bandwagon. perhaps it's a peer pressure thing. or a job security thing. but whatever his (hidden -- perhaps even to himself) motivation, it isn't science. not yet. perhaps we cannot be reduced to mere machines. a radical thought for materialists, i realize. but it hasn't yet been shown -- esp. in the language instinct area of science -- that we are mere machines. serious study of human neurological areas requires reduction. but we appear to be far more than the sum of our parts. and a book such as this one or a scientist such as steven pinker adds to our knowledge. no doubt. but they really might up the ante on their methods by retaining at least a modicum of mystery to their method. imo.

This was certainly an illuminating read, even if it is slightly out of date-there was a significant portion of one chapter that was entirely dedicated to the lack of machine ability to listen to and understand or respond to language. Since 1994, circumstances have definitely changed. That was the only obvious dating that I could tell of the material in the book. I'm sure there are others that are more niche in the linguistics field, all of which would have been far beyond me. Although the book is sold as being laymen-accessible, I really don't think that that was always the case. Often, Pinker would "explain" certain constructions of language that I didn't find particularly accessible. Mostly because I don't think I had the necessary linguistics background, or perhaps the jargon, I really couldn't connect with what was being said, though I always understood the point he was trying to make. I didn't really hold this against Pinker, as trying to explain the nuances of how individuals create language is vastly more complex than the way the language learners understand their language abilities. Ultimately, I recommend this to individuals who are looking for a book about language creation. Pinker's argument (as can be inferred from the title) is that individuals have a language instinct, it is not a recurring invention. I would have enjoyed a little more on the evolutionary aspect of things, but the taste included in this book was very interesting. I loved the chapter "The Language Mavens," it really highlights Pinker's humor throughout the book, as well as being amazingly entertaining. This was very engaging, mostly pleasurable read.

I originally bought this book as supplemental reading for one of my linguistics classes, but didn't read the whole thing at that point. Then I saw Steven Pinker speak and so when I found this book at my parents house I decided to give it a go.In the past, I have been known to down-rate scientific books if they are outdated. I am definitely interested in reading some of Pinker's more recent stuff but this book was great. I think one of his biggest strengths as a writer, speaker, and scholar is his knowledge of what people are interested in reading. While putting forth a serious theory (and I do classify this as science because of its basis in evolutionary biology) he uses humor and interesting examples to illustrate his points.This book is geared to the non-specialist. There is a glossary in the back and lots of information that will be familiar to anyone who has taken an intro to linguistics class. I would like to read a book that takes the opposite view (if there is a recently written one--I really don't know about current developments in cognitive sciences); Pinker is pretty convincing but I don't like to hear only one side of a story.One of my favorite chapters in the book was where he talks about "language mavens" and speaks out against prescriptive grammar. I used to be really into grammar and correcting people but a few years ago when I became a meta-snob (my own personal term meaning a snob about not being a snob) I stopped doing that so I enjoyed his criticism of "standard grammar."

In the Silent Language, the classic treatise on culture and of anthropology, Edward T. Hall explains the expression and communication of culture including language - Pinker would differ. Far from being an expression of culture, Pinker argues that recent research points to the idea that language is hard wired. He explains that we have innate tendencies and capabilities that manifest based on context but that these manifestations of a language capability in humans follows uniform and predictable patterns. In order to make his point, Pinker explores everything from biology and neurology to psychology and comparative linguistics.While Pinker lost me on his discussion of linguistic models which sound like equations that prove the laws of physics, the book is surprisingly readable. Pinker gives dozens of fun, funny examples of language in action which serve to bring his ideas back to reality regardless of how abstract his discussion of hard science becomes. Ultimately, Pinker's argument is compelling. Thinking of language as a set of sounds and syntax leads one to imagine that a language like Mandarin could have nothing to do with Old Norse, but the point isn't the system of sounds. When sounds are taken in sequence, the same physiology determines that "i" "o" "u" will go in that sequence. When syntax differs, it is an inverse, never an arbitrary variation. I enjoyed the book and gained understanding of how language develops. I would recommend this to anyone with an interest in language or human development.

I enjoyed this book up until chapter 12. His argument that prescriptive grammar is useless and that it is not English at all is absolutely pathetic. He has no real ground for his argument and it is just a bunch of meaningless opinion. In his other chapters , his arguments had excellent studies and empirical data but this chapter seemed as though it was just pushed into the book because he was mad at his editor. Honestly, it took down the overall quality of the book. I agree that human language (no matter the dialect) is human language and shouldn't have to be corrected by extremists who don't understands the differences between standard English and Black Standard English. But when speaking American standard English , one should follow the rules laid out for them. Also, his history of how grammar rules were established seemed a little sketchy. Ok...a lot sketchy. It wasn't some ploy to control the mass populous and feel superior to others. At that time, there were different dialects in English that made it hard to communicate via papers or even just speaking to one another. So , enthusiasts came together and made rules for the benefit of all. My argument is: if you want to speak American standard English and speak it properly, you should obey the rules laid before you. Other than that, the book was very insightful and pragmatic. Overall, I loved the book and enjoyed the read. I recommend this reading to anyone who is interested in linguistics (or in debate). It is definitely a "must read".

More properly, this would be a 3.5. I really enjoyed the early parts of the book, and they were a solid 4 stars. However, the book dragged at the end, and that would warrant more of a 3 star rating. I'm not a linguist. I just have a passing interest in the subject, so I can't really comment on the validity of Pinker's arguments. I can say that what he argued made sense to me most of the time, with a few small exceptions, and I wouldn't be surprised if he is mostly correct. But I'm not an expert. So, there's that. As for writing style, Pinker does pretty well. As I said above, the book started very well for me. I think Pinker has an engaging writing style and that he uses examples to illustrate his points quite well. Unfortunately, he does sometimes get bogged down in the minutiae. I understand that the grammar discussions were important to make his point, but I felt like the way he just threw you into them was a bit abrupt. I spent a good long while reading grammar descriptions without being sure what the ultimate point was going to be. That may have been a problem with my reading, but I think Pinker could also have been more upfront about where he was going with it. Either way, I enjoyed the book, and would recommend it for language geeks like myself. At times it may be a bit technical, but as long as you keep on keeping on, you'll come out with a broader understanding of the language mechanism in human beings.

Didn't finish this book; unconvincing, dull, repetitive, and not well supported.As an avid reader, and a not-so-avid writer, yes, I do find language interesting. I was hoping in this book to find some science on language, and how it could have evolved. Instead I found a pile of stuffy nonsense, full of opinion and short on facts. I did not finish this book, after realizing it was (for the great part) bullshit.The writer intends to confuse, I would swear, going on and on about the most dull long-winded points that amounted to nothing, while anything that could have a possibility of substance was disregarded and glossed over.While venting my doubts and frustration about the book to Caleb one day I was surprised to learn he knew of the theories in the book, and he let me know that they're pretty much considered disregarded at this point. I'm not sorry that I started reading the book, because honestly sometimes I question my critical thinking skills. I often feel like I am easily influenced by others thought and opinions to an extent that I hardly have any of my own, and I am nothing but a chameleon. Not that it is wrong to be influenced by others; nothing in this world is original; but I hate feeling as if I am just a leaf in the wind. Being able to detect the poorly constructed arguments in this book did not necessarily make me feel less influenced, but it did give me some sort of hope that I do have a critical bone, somewhere in my body.

This should definitely be on the list of any lover of language, and they should probably even get around to reading it. I didn't notice the date on this book (1994) until after I bought it at the public library's Friends of the Library basement bookshop. It only cost me two bucks, so that's cool, and it's very interesting and insightful. And Pinker, who always strikes me as blithely brilliant, inserts just enough smartassery to make you wonder if it's too much and then to decide that no, it is not, but it's *almost.* And damned if he isn't great at simplifying complex information and theory without *over*simplifying, and at not overselling his theories and conjectures -- he always acknowledges them as theory and conjecture. That's nice. Tell me the truth and let me decide what to mine from it. What more can you ask of a book?But 1994. Sheesh. It's that magic time between 'So Old It's Only Good for Ideas and Not Anything Definitive Like Research' and 'Fresh, Hot-Off-The-Press" research. Since it's neither, it's nearly useless in terms of any academic pursuit beyond rank, raw interest and hobby. And maybe pursuing the current research to see what seems silly or misguided now in retrospect. But still, it's fascinating as hell. Even an obsessive armchair linguist like this professor learned some things. Enjoy.

I enjoyed this read, though I found it to be really dense and it took me a long while to finish it. Since it was originally published in 1994, I found some of the content to be a bit outdated, but it was still packed with a lot of goofy “aha” moments about language. Many sections had me babbling to myself, testing out examples that were provided (I mostly read this at home, so as not to disturb other people). I first learned about Steven Pinker when he gave a presentation at my university essentially summarizing The Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined (i.e. global violence has actually declined over time, here’s how--with statistics--, and here are six main hypotheses/reasons why). It's a concept that interests me, so I looked him up and found his work on cognitive science and language. The Language Instinct is kind of for a niche audience (and you’ll know who you are). For the less-committed, I’d recommend trying Pinker's TED talks, which are only 20 minute investments of time and more approachable for a lay audience.

This is listed as one of the New Scientist Top 25 Most Influential Popular Science books. The thesis is solid...the execution burdensome. Here's a thought: make a point; reinforce a point; if at that point you feel the need to keep talking, show the reader where in the footnotes or appendix all the repetitious extras can be found. Pinker spends an enormous amount of time talking about language grammar and the English language in particular, none of which have anything to do with why language is instinctual. It would have been a lot more tedious if I hadn't just listened to John McWhorter's lectures on The Story of Human language. The parallels could not have been coincidental...both relating elements of language development, grammar structure, proto-languages...but McWhorter wasn't talking about instinct. He was talking about language. Pinker undermines his case with all the side trips down linguist lane. Focus on instinct, not on the idiosyncrasies of a hodgepodge tongue. Pinker could have made his point very well in 100 pages. I admire succinct conveyance of knowledge. Pinker sure has a way of complicating concepts with extraneous details. I didn't admire this book.

I had read almost every single book written by Steven Pinker except this one. He is one of the most skilled contemporary writers, but The Language Instinct proves that writing is a skill that is developed over time. This book is not bad by any means (it's great) but it's occasionally repetitive and Pinker's trademarks, such as the use of comic strips as a comic relief, are missing. His jaunty personality is occasionally overshadowed by his almost homicidal hatred toward what he calls as the Standard Social Science Model (SSSM), which also makes him slip into strawman-like oversimplifications of it. I agree with Pinker that SSSM is mostly just silly, and thus it was easy for me to agree with his arguments even when I noticed how easily some of them could be challenged. Richard Dawkins' works have also clearly influenced him as a young author and I felt that this is The Extended Phenotype translated into linguistics. In spite of all that, I learned a lot that I didn't know before and I nodded in agreement more often than I shook my head, which makes this a book that I wholeheartedly recommend.

I am a polyglot and fascinated by languages and language learning/acquisition and how they relate to the human experience. I am also an academic and translator who loves reading about these topics from an academic perspective.This book presented many of the themes about language and the human experience that interest me, but the style is not necessarily one that appeals to me. That is not really a comment about the quality of the book and the information but more about my own personal preference. Pinker takes a strongly linguistics-based approach, which is not the way I necessarily think about language. I know that might seem contradictory or unusual, but linguistics tend to use scientific methodology (especially categorical terminology) to explore and explain language. I personally do not find that approach useful or interesting, though I understand why many do.Overall, Pinker offers many valuable observations about language, human experience, and the brain, but the overly linguistic approach did not strongly appeal to me. I'm sure it would to others who enjoy a linguistic approach to studying languages, human behavior, and physiology.

Couldn't put it down. Another interesting set of insights by Mr Pinker."A language is a dialect with an army and a navy"-Max WeinreichThere are developed and underdeveloped economies, but there is no such thing as an underdeveloped grammar. All people, everywhere in the world, speak with a grammar of equal complexity. We (including myself!) hear blacks in the US use very strange "uneducated" sounding english. As a matter of fact, the black population has their own dialect inherited from the days of slavery.Children everywhere on earth learn to speak on their own, without assistance from their parents like the "mommy talk" that is popular in the west. Children don't need to be trained to speak, just like they don't need to be trained to walk. We'll all do it on our own.As we age, we loose the ability go "grow" language. If someone is to be 100% bilingual, the younger they are immersed in the target environment the better. After six or seven, most children loose the ability to develop the native gramar for a language.

The main thesis of this book: We are not born as blank slates. We are born with some pretty impressive intellectual machinery that just needs to be oiled and put to work. I am glad I read it but can’t say I’ll be recommending it to others. That said, I will be annoying my friends talking about the main points. For example, his bashing of language “mavens” is great. I enjoyed how he ripped apart the argument that language is falling apart. I also found his ridicule of certain “rules” of language - like not splitting infinitives or ending a sentence with a preposition - to be liberating. He also makes a direct attack on the racist arguments against “black” language and showed how rich and expressive all dialects are. And I found his belief that the brain is made up of various innate computing centers pretty interesting and compelling - and very cool. The last 3 chapters of this book are great. 5 star chapters. However, to get the most out of those chapters you do need to read all the previous chapters - which, for me, were a bit slow, repetitive, and incredibly dense.

This book is a great introduction to linguistics. Pinker shows how humans have an innate language learning module which allows children to rapidly hone in on the correct generalizations of grammar from a few examples, easily avoiding the multitude of other seemingly valid generalizations that could be inferred. It neatly summarizes past linguistic research, highlighting insights on how language processing is localized in the brain, the common threads between different languages and the fundamentals of phonology and morphology. He challenges the so-called language mavens by walking the reader through flaws in their logic - for instance why do they insist on "whom" when they can bear the loss of "ye"? Linguistic ideas that are often presented as fact in textbooks are exposed as myth, one example being the classic "Eskimos have 100 different words for snow" which turns out to be totally false. Overall you come away from the book with an appreciation for the astonishing complexity and speed of language processing and the striking universality of many of the features of language.

Outstanding book. As an undergraduate Linguistics major in 1979, I was familiar with many (but not all) of the topics and enjoyed the book completely. It was a like the summary of the entire major in a single book! What a great experience it would have been to have Pinker as your professor. The writing is so clear, it is so refreshing. I can understand how many might get lost in the technical analysis of language, but they should give it a try. Amidst all the technical explanations are gems of insight, anecdotes, and humor - but it takes patience to get through it - unless you were taking exams in it 40 years ago! I am amazed how much I have remembered! In this single book, language history, sociolinguistics, psycholinguistics, neurolinguistics are summarized with clarity and humor. I am truly disappointed that the book was published in 1994 - that's 24 years ago. I can only imagine how much more there is to add to all these topics. I guess I'll have to find other authors to bring me up to date!

Obviously, Steven Pinker’s “The Language Instinct” is a monumental work, one of the seminal works of modern social science. I had read this book many years ago and have heard it referred to frequently since. That’s why I wanted to go back and give it another listen. And you know what? It wasn’t a great read for understanding the core concepts — at least in audiobook form, there’s too much statistical data, too much math, too many things that I’m sure are fine in diagram form but are just plain confusing in prose. Maybe it works as a textbook (and it is used as one), but as a book to read, there are other books and writers that describe the concepts with more clarity (though, to be fair, Pinker is a good writer who displays wit and a sense of style) and less “under the hood” jargon. I don’t really blame Pinker — I probably am not his audience, and I definitely prefer a “science for poets” approach when listening to an audiobook. If that’s what you’re looking for, this book is still brilliant but perhaps a bit overwhelming — I stopped about 2/3 of the way through.Grade: B-/DNF

To be rated/reviewedThe author is clearly an expert who is passionate about his field of study and was easily able to transfer that passion to the page. However, it still read a bit like a scientific/academic treatise, which made me end up skimming certain parts -- especially when I felt like he was repeating points he'd already clearly proven. Nevertheless, I did find this an interesting read and enjoyed being reminded of the linguistics courses I took in college. I suspect that I would not have skimmed as much if I'd read it closer to my college days and could've seen it sparking lively discussions with other students and my professors. If you have a casual interest in linguistics or language acquisition, you may find this a bit dry despite the author's efforts to make the material lively. Regardless of your background in the topic or interest level prior to reading it, this will challenge you to think about language differently and will likely teach you something new.

3.5Interesting but not as interesting as I had hoped for. Steven Pinker sounds so much like Richard Dawkins!The book is making a case for the thesis that some kind of language facility is hardwired in human brain. It presents variety of arguments, and results from scientific experiments to buttress the claim. Pinker makes a good case but along the way he keeps shooting off on tangents. Like a chapter on language mavens the sole purpose of which seems to be to write off certain people he doesn't like much. It is a pretty lengthy book and such diversions could have easily been avoided.Many parts of the book, especially those related to syntax, parse trees etc were familiar to me from before so I skipped them. Cannot comment on how accessible he has been able to make those for someone without any background in the area.I wouldn't mind reading a shorter and more updated version of this. May be even by another author.

Certain parts of Steven Pinker's The Language Instinct are utterly fascinating, as he explains how language itself works, regardless of the specific language being spoken. However, this book delves into super-academic jargon so far that I largely skimmed entire pages, particularly those where he outlines the mental grammar rules that dictate how all languages are built. There were insights that required that level of depth to understand, however this book is definitely not for a lay person with a vague interest in how language works. I will probably remember certain details (in particular, the difference between a pidgin language and a creole language developed by the descendants of those who speak pidgin, which is always more complex than the pidgin language even if the children develop the creole language in isolation), but overall can only recommend this book if you have a deep interest in the subject.

A solid book with an interesting argument, plenty of details, plenty of interesting asides, and a wide purview of language... plus a very compelling argument in favor of not only a language instinct, but a specifically developed language circuitry in the brain (duh). So yes, the book dives deeply into the subject. Deeply enough, perhaps, to lose you every now and then—but Pinker always comes up for air and generally scatters enough lively examples in that you'll stay your course. If you don't like sentence trees, X-bars, and other inane linguistic nattering, this book may still be for you, since those aspects are thoroughly covered rather quickly and effectively, and then the author moves on to the big stuff, which is wickedly interesting, and most definitely worth reading and learning about.

Excellent overview of Chomsky's theory of generative grammar and an enlighting dialectic of culture vs. nature for human language. Argues in favor of considering language as an mostly innate function of the human. A result of evolution and natural selection. But with a careful delineation of what is thought to be innate (universal grammar, speech production organs etc. with openings on neurosciences) and what is the result of individual adaptation to environnent (the actual language instance, French, English, accents and dialects, vocabulary etc. and this killing argument of Creole languages being children invention). Finally a very accurate list of arguments against language "experts" and their non-sense of correcteness. This last part could have been opened to more political/sociological issues regarding use of "standard" language as a tool for domination.

I liked this book, but I struggled with some parts because I'm not a native English speaker, and I got bored with the details of the Universal Grammar. (I also found a little cringeworthy to see Universal Grammar capitalized; it makes the whole thing feel like a sect.)That said, when I read books like this I'm looking for new ideas and to change how I perceive the world. This book excels in both things. And even if I'm not qualified to have an opinion on the Chomsky debate, I like to know that it exists, and to have a very basic understanding of the arguments in favor of the (here we go again) Universal Grammar.And one more thing: these "idea books" tend to have a lot of fluff in the final chapters. Here, in my opinion, the final chapters are some of the best. Chapter 11, on why a language instinct can have a Darwinian explanation, was probably my favorite.

Took me a long while to work through. A few chapters exemplify the challenge of transcribing an academic linguists knowledge into a form accessible for popular science readers. Pinker tackles this with clarity and examples that are easy to relate.There is plenty I gained from this text. As someone working in children's education, it was perhaps lacking in applicable knowledge, but as a curious learner it was quite insightful. Touching topics of natural selection, brain science, education, culture, parenting, linguistics. Language Instinct is perhaps more expansive than I expected but this benefits ita main thesis that the capacity to learn language is innate to humans. It is compelling, but perhaps would benefit from updating in light of contemporary neuroimaging and cognitive science.

In this book, Pinker takes his theory on how language is partly genetically encoded in humans and dissects it. It does a great job at showcasing both it's strengths and weaknesses. Each chapter takes a different approach, so the best way to read it is with slight pauses between the chapters so you can digest what it was trying to convey and how it reflects on other topics like natural selection, grammar, art or history. I was already accustomed with and a fan of Pinker's style and ideas, so there was a lot of confirmation bias for me to enjoy this one (which I'm unapologetic about). There were plenty of ideas in the book I was unaware of and ways of looking at language that I never thought of. I'm pretty satisfied with it since it lead me to update my view on how the mind creates and molds communication.

Pinker is one of those wacky, made-for-TV, pop-science wonks with his big hair, scientism/humanism bent, and gentle Canadian patience. But this was actually quite good. Pinker writes with minimal academese and does a decent job explaining Chomsky's theories of Universal Grammar. The wheels fall off in the final chapters with Pinker's blind faith in Darwinian natural selection, and it's a shame to see him try to explain away the irreducible complexity of human language with the old favourite "but over millions of years anything is possible". He'd have been better off sticking with Chomsky's "we just don't know." Still, there's more good in here than bad. Pinker's a witty chap who writes about philology with a clear passion. I'm doubtful his newer, more political stuff is worth the price of entry though.

I liked it a lot, despite a certain prevention I have to "experts in language". In the book I have discovered that the people I dislike are the "language mavens" who try to preserve absurd prescriptive rules. The fundamental rules of language are universal, and all 3-year-old human beings uses them to analyse theirs' parents speech and re-invent a language. In the case of parents or caretakers speaking a pidgin, the children invent a new language: a creole.From the last page of the book:"Among laypeople, race is lamentable salient, but for biologists it is virtually invisible. Race is, quite literally, skin deep.[...]For a psycholinguist, not speaking the same language is a superficial difference: we all have the same minds."

This is some good stuff. We have had the mental faculties to learn language for tens of thousands of years, but to explain how or why it works is not simple. Some of it is innate in our ability, and sets us apart from other animals that roam the earth. But language acquisition is also conditioned or learned, because we cannot learn language in isolation or after a critical period of development, lest we become a feral child and unable to learn language for the rest of our life. There are those who can speak syntactically correct sentences like "Colorless green ideas sleep furiously" and make no sense. There are those who are otherwise bright but have a difficult time communicating.Turns out, language acquisition is an interesting business.

When I read this book I want to pass it around like a joint and tell people what good shit it is. "Seriously, man, you gotta try it. It'll blow your mind." My scalp tingled with excitement through chapters of linguistic minutiae and scientific cross-pollination, from neuroscience to biology to anthropology through to computer coding and poetry and authentic frontier gibberish. Pinker is one hell of a writer, and his persuasive style is one to envy, at once confident and humble and also hella funny. Even when I'm skeptical of a given conclusion he draws (his take-downs of competing theories are occasionally less effective, given the scope he chooses as examples) I feel enlightened by the exploration. Seriously, dude. It's a super high.

An excellent book on how we can begin to understand the inner workings of language. It takes us away from the Whorfian idea of speaking a language influences how you see the world, but rather we are all born with the innate faculties to speak. The so called Language instinct. For example babies when learning their parents language, display grammatical errors that they could not have learnt from their parents but rather by filling in the blanks themselves. This refutes the idea that babies are a 'blank slate', instead they have a mental framework in place to begin to learn the language. As an amateur in linguistics hoping to improve my knowledge this was a good foundation and introduced a lot of topics in linguistics from core stuff like phonetics to sub fields like neurolinguisrics.

When reading this book (or deciding if you want to read it) you should keep in mind that it is more than 20 years old. So some of Pinker's concepts and ideas are simply outdated. He added and afterword ten years later to set some things straight but still you should be careful about some facts especially the ones concerning brain research.He uses some of Chomsky's ideas which Chomsky himself by now declares as being incorrect.Pinker gets pretty much down to the basics, explaining what a noun phrase is and so on. Don't expect an all to easy read and don't expect to many news if you already have a basic knowledge of linguistics and children's language acquisition. His ideas might have been ground-breaking in 1994 but are a bit dated by now.

Can be pretty daunting for the untrained eye, especially all the terms and vocabulary from linguistics. However, Pinker takes us to a mesmerizing journey to the depths of human brain and history of its development in the context of language learning and creation. He adds also many studies and academic trivia to fill in fact for the doubters and claims that language was a natural way to evolve human race. As a teacher and educator, I will come back to this book in upcoming research and quote bits and pieces as same as using it as a reference to more academic studies.It was 1-year road to understanding my students better and in fact understanding better the entire process of learning, remembering, categorizing and structuring language.

Deep topic well written. The only part I had trouble following was some of the sentence diagrams. Did a good job of seamlessly integrating special vocabulary and terminology. A little dissappointed that he didn't root concepts a bit more firmaly in evolutionary biology, but then remembered that he wrote this 20 years ago and was actually far ahead of his time and anticipated some of the discoveries since irst puplication.Dynamic speaker and entertaining enlightening writer. Three more of his books in my reading pipeline for this year should get me caught up.Fascinating how many hugely complicated mental processes we take for granted. Language and its acquisition are quite a bit both clearer and cloudier after reading this book.

Lively to read, well-reasoned, fun; some of Pinker's pop-culture references are now a bit dated, but hey--I'm about his age & so they worked for me.This was Pinker's first written-for-the-layperson book, but I have found many books I now want to read based upon his list of references.As a person who teaches writing, I find his observations on the differences between natural and prescriptive grammar fascinating and useful. As a person who's pretty convinced that there is no mind-body "problem"--our minds are embodied, I think--his Darwin-based theories of language evolution convince me; but I know his work is controversial (and I have read some of his sources who are at odds with his theories, and they are thought-provoking, too).

Certainly a challenging read. Some material was above me and the scope of the book was wide I found a little overwhelming. However, I felt that this book was worthwhile. A reread is required and exposure to other linguistic texts necessary, as I'm not in any sort of position to judge Pinker's belief in a innate Universal Grammar. His arguments were impressive and he does a brilliant job highlighting the amazing talents that children have in acquiring spoken language. It certainly seems plausible that language acquisition is too complex to learn via instruction. Pinker's anecdotes are numerous, humorous and cement his theory. Wish I could give a better chapter by chapter run down but I just recall all that info.

Language is one thing which is universal to all humans, piercing the physical and mental barriers. It binds us as a species and gives us a unique position in the animal kingdom, so much so that acquisition of language is a water-shed movement in the history of civilizations. Steven Pinker, a renowed psychologist and linguist, who wrote "The Language Instinct" in the year 1994. It is a thoroughly researched book about some clinching questions from the world of linguistics.Before actually discussing about the book, it is important to give some key takeaways from the massive piece of work. These key points will help you determine, if at all you would want to pick up this book. 1. Language is not a cultural artifact that we learn through nurture, but part of a complex and specialised part of our brains, ingrained in our biological makeup. The Language Instinct is wired in our brains at an unconscious level. It's innate and universal. 2. There is a Universal Common Grammar amongst humans, irrespective of the language. The idea of Universal Common Grammar has been heavily borrowed from Noam Chomsky's research and the book builds upon it by saying that babies don't learn grammar rules from their parents from a young age, but still are able to speak grammatically correct sentences. It is an argument based on the premise that some grammar rules are part of our genetical and biological code, making it easier for young kids and babies to speak grammatically, irrespective of learning. It is a common sentence structure that we all share since birth, with some natural variations in different languages. For more on this topic, I am putting a link here which is a small-brief on the concept of Universal Common Grammar (https://www.britannica.com/topic/univ...) 3. There is a language of thought called Mentalese. We do not require words necessarily to think, since thought process has its own language. Supporting linguistic relativity, Pinker says that thoughts of the speaker require something beyond words, which is mentalese. Simply put, mentalese is the idea that humans think in visual terms through representations, in a pictorial form rather than in a literal sense using words. "Representational theory of mind" would mean that our brains are wired to think in terms of images and not words, which is why babies even though are unable to speak are scientifically known to have thought process. (Note: An interesting article here which questions mentalese for bilingual speakers- https://vc.bridgew.edu/cgi/viewconten...) 4. Why are there more than one languages, if all humans come equipped with the same instinct and biological program? Well, Steven after drawing from Darwin's theory of evolution, points out three main reasons for linguistic diversity among humans: Innovation, learning and migration. There is a selective pressure on humans to make language and speech an innate part of their system, in order to fully cooperate with other similarly situated humans around as well as to ensure survival of the race. It also focuses on ability of humans to reanalyse the words of the speaker and innovate something completely unique from it. (Interesting fact: @pg. 249- He discusses Sanskrit as world's oldest language which has mind-boggling similarities with earlier languages spoken in West)5. In nature v. nurture debate, it is nature which wins. Babies do not learn language from their parents, what they learn essentially is how to use speech and vocabulary. Learning of grammar is inherent, and therefore need not be a necessary requirement of outside nurture. We also know that it is difficult to acquire a second language in adulthood, rather than in childhood, for the simple reason that our neural circuits concerning language are at their peak in early childhood making it easier to pick up different languages. 6. You can see language in action in the left hemisphere of most right-handed persons and in right hemisphere in left-handed persons. There is no single organ or part of the brain, but a complex activity centre in the left hemisphere which develops our language instinct and decodes our grammar code. Now, let's see how this book comes across to a reader.  Writing an interesting book is not enough, if it extremely difficult and unintelligible to read. Keeping in mind that not many readers are going to be linguistics, cognitive scientists or psychologists, this book is supremely technical for layman. A book which is interesting and painful to go through in equal measures. While his research and arguments are convincing, it makes for highly academic read. A person with a background in any of the aforementioned fields would be more well-versed in reading a heavy piece of research, rather than persons who like popular science. It required some easy to understand and accessible writing.   This book is heavily influenced by Noam Chomsky's work and research, and Pinker openly admits to the same in the book. Also Pinker relies heavily on Darwin to substantiate his arguments. Therefore, anyone who has either read Chomsky or Darwin earlier can find this work a good piece of research. The scientific urge to get to the bottom of questions, which we may have wondered at some point of time, will rub on the readers, provided one reads it with patience and high-levels of concentration.
