The best summary of the Language Instinct I found in another Pinker book, The Blank Slate: "Language is based on a combinatorial grammar designed to communicate an unlimited number of thoughts. It is utilized by people in real time via an interplay of memory lookup and rule application. It is implemented in a network of regions in the center of the left cerebral hemisphere that must coordinate memory, planning, word meaning, and grammar. It develops in the first three years of life in a sequence from babbling to words to word combinations, including errors in which rules may be overapplied. It evolved through modifications of a vocal tract and brain circuitry that had other uses in earlier primates, because the modifications allowed our ancestors to prosper in a socially interconnected, knowledge-rich lifestyle."What Pinker does is present Noam Chomsky's revolutionary theory of deep grammar as an evolved adaptation of the species. Chomsky was skeptical that universal grammar could be explained by the process of natural selection, and so that is where this book takes off: to match cognitive linguistics to the Neo-Darwinian paradigm. Chomsky's theory is that language has an innate structure in the mind, like a computer has built in hardware. Though languages may differ in gender pronouns or the order of noun to verb, all languages have a universal structure. Latin has gendered pronouns compared to English, but whether pronouns are gendered or not is a reality all languages have. Every language has a noun phrase and a verb phrase regardless of the word order. "Pigs fly" is about a simple sentence as one can get; pigs is the noun phrase and fly is the verb phrase. Also universal is the auxiliary which tells something about the relation of noun and verb. "Pigs don't fly." The auxiliary is parallel to the copula in logic (are, are not): ScP. The auxiliary belongs to the noun phrase. In every language there is an object an action, just as in logic there is a subject, a copula and a predicate.This fundamental division of language and logic into the relation of noun-verb and subject-predicate is related to the perception of the world into space and time. Things can be separated into objects which persist in time in different spaces and do different things in particular times and places. This is advantageous for the survival of the species. "It's a jungle out there, and the organism designed to make successful predictions about what is going to happen next will leave behind more babies designed just like it. Slicing space-time into objects and actions is an eminently sensible way to make predictions given the way the world is put together...Look away, and the rabbit still exists." There are two rules used to convey meaning: Saussure's arbitrariness of the sign which pairs sound with conventional meaning and Wilhelm Von Humboldt´s "language makes infinite use of finite media." A sign can stand for just about anything, and the combination of words with recursion, reuse of phrases, can produce seemingly infinite words with different meanings. "The way language works, then, is that each person's brain contains a lexicon of words and the concepts they stand for (a mental dictionary) and a set of rules that combine the words to convey relationships among concepts (a mental grammar)."Pinker criticizes the influential Sapir-Whorf hypothesis: that language determines or is necessary for any conscious awareness. It would be strange if animals had no awareness at all. From an evolutionary standpoint this is absurd as humans evolved from a non-speaking common ancestor. The hard version of Sapir-Whorf is linguistic determinism, the weak version is linguistic relativity that language shapes our perception. Infants and animals exhibit a basic cognitive ability to differentiate things. The claims Sapir-Whorf relies on are reports of languages which lack words for certain colors. What experiments show, in particular the one by Elizabeth Rosch with the Dani people, is that people are able to understand a color in relation to ones they have words for. As Pinker says, it would be incredulous that language could alter what the physiological senses give us, and rewire the cones, rods, and retina of our eyes. Language is an adaptation itself rooted in physiology, though I think sentient awareness is a different thing than self-consciousness which requires language."Though most common words have many meaning, few meanings have more than one word. That is, homonyms are plentiful, synonyms rare."This goes to dissuade fears of a George Orwell 1984 future where language is used to alter people´s perception of reality. In his famous essay Politics and the English Language Orwell argued that totalitarian regimes justified their actions by debasing language into simple emotional phrases that are either totally positive or totally negative. Ideas can be condensed into unambiguous phrases and ideally into single words which will invert the natural human suspicion of power into total submission, like Miniluv for the ministry of love which tortures people. While this may be a more effective means of state communication and propaganda, it isn´t going to destroy our perception of reality."The twenty first century toddler may be Winston Smith's revenge."Several organs are used in the production of speech: the vocal cords, the trachea, the tongue and the mouth. Air leaves the lungs through the trachea (windpipe) which opens into the larynx (voice box, visible as the Adam's apple). The larynx is a valve with an opening covered by two flaps of muscle tissue called vocal cords but really are vocal folds. The frequency of vocal folds opening and closing determines pitch. Our brains process language in the left hemisphere: Wernicke's area is associated with language understanding and Broca's area is associated with production of language. Language production usually begins at age one, word combination at one and a half, and fluent grammatical sentences at two or three. Infants can already distinguish between sounds and have a basic mental language, ¨mentalese.¨We think with mental representations, not just with a particular language. This is what computers do with their operating systems for us. "People do not think in English or Chinese or Apache; they think in a language of thought...There must be extra paraphernalia that differentiate logically distinct kinds of concepts." "People without a language would still have mentalese", like non-human animals and infants do.¨The behaviorist perspective influential to the mid-twentieth century denied a language of thought or any consciousness not translatable to observable behavior. There is no basic language of thought which is universal, programmed in us. It is all learned as individuals. A passage from another Pinker book How the Mind Works is useful here:"The computational theory of mind also rehabilitates once and for all the infamous homunculus. A standard objection to the idea that thoughts are internal representations (an objection popular among scientists trying to show how tough-minded they are) is that a representation would require a little man in the head to look at it, and the little man would require an even littler man to look at the representations inside him, and so on, ad infinitum...Why doesn't all this homunculus talk lead to an infinite regress? Because an internal representation is not a lifelike photograph of the world, and the homunculus that 'looks at it' is not a miniaturized copy of the entire system, requiring its entire intelligence. That indeed would explain nothing. Instead, a representation is a set of symbols corresponding to aspects of the world, and each homunculus is required only to react in a few circumscribed ways to some of the symbols, a feat far simpler than what the system as a whole does. The intelligence of the system emerges from the activities of the not-so-Intelligent mechanical demons inside of it."The homunculi would correspond to neurons in our brains and transistors in computers I guess. The functions they do collectively are conscious awareness. Consciousness as internal representations do exist, and so does mentalese. From Karen Wynn´s experiments we see that five month infants can do simple mental arithmetic: show a baby a bunch of objects long enough and the baby gets bored and looks away; change the scene and the baby notices the difference and is interested. Five day old babies are also sensitive to number; they notice if when screen removed and more objects are there such as when two Mickey Mouse dolls is placed behind a curtain and notice if the second one taken away. Given these abilities and others also observed in animals we see it is possible to have mental software which can build towards language comprehension and production.For language to be an instinct, there needs to be credible evolutionary mechanisms. BF Skinner whose view of language was opposite of Chomsky's said that instinct just means what we haven't found an explanation for. Instinct for Pinker means innate or heritable, having a basis in our biology and shared by all humans in normal course of development. Natural selection requires different forms of language which can be selected from. Proto-languages would include chimp signing, pidgin, child language in two word stage, and partial language of children raised by children. "The languages of children, pidgin speakers, immigrants, tourists, aphasics, telegrams, and headlines show that there is a vast continuum of viable language systems varying in efficiency and expressive power, exactly what the theory of natural selection requires." Pidgin is a language formed by speakers of different languages, and aphasia is damage to the left brain hemisphere which impairs language.One must be careful with speculations for how language began, otherwise we end up with just-so stories which may be useful and entertaining but lack proof. Pinker mentions the Throwing Madonna hypothesis that the reason why most people are right-handed is because prehistoric mothers held their babies with their left arm to calm them with the heartbeat, and so the right hand was free to throw stones at small game. These women survived and passed on their genes, by both pacifying their fussy babies and contributing to the hunt. It´s a fascinating story but its hard to imagine how to prove this is the reason why most people around the world are right-handed and left brain dominant. Such stories tend to discredit evolutionary psychology in the minds of critics, so we can come up with scenarios for how language could evolve but it is better to search for data.The language mutant baby could have had siblings to talk to, and other family members would have had other more primitive means of communication, which would have given an advantage to the language mutants. Pinker does think language serves important services for our survival against the environment and in social life. "If contemporary hunter gatherers are any guide, our ancestors were not grunting cave men with little more to talk about than which mastodon to avoid. Hunter gatherers are accomplished toolmakers and superb amateur biologists with detailed knowledge of the life cycles, ecology, and behavior of the plants and animals they depend on. Language would surely have been useful in anything resembling such a lifestyle...People everywhere depend on cooperative efforts for survival, forming alliances by exchanging information and commitments."I think sexual selection could also have been a mechanism. Sexual selection occurs when males compete with other males for females and the females choose who to mate with. The selection process is about what can signal greater fitness, in terms of resource provision among other things. The book The Mating Mind argues that intelligence evolved this way by sexual selection as an ornament to impress females like the feathers of the male peacock. Much of our intellect is not about struggling against the environment and definitely doesn´t reflect reality, but demonstrates our ability to expend energy and time to such superfluous social activities like a handicap.Keep in mind that written language is not an instinct. Written language is a late development in human history and is not universal. This is why reading disorders like dyslexia are with us even in our literate societies. Alphabets don't correspond to sounds, at best they correspond to the phonemes of the mental dictionary. Foreigners can usually spell better than they pronounce, as according to Bernard Shaw fish can be spelled as ghoti.Just because language is an instinct doesn't make it not special, just as the fact that birds are designed to fly doesn't make the feat less impressive to us. The big takeaway of The Language Instinct is language is a universal human adaptation with a basis in biology and evolution. No matter how different various human languages are, they share basic structure. This means accepting that there is such a thing as a scientifically meaningful human nature that has something to do with biology and evolution. This belief may be politically incorrect for some people, but it also means on a fundamental level we are the same and can understand one another. I also take away from The Language Instinct that folk language, like folk psychology, isn´t really wrong or useless. Of course it often is wrong from a scientific point of view and science does require precise technical language, but for the purpose of communication mentalese is fine. This was Ludwig Wittgenstein´s insight: that the nature of language is public, and so we can understand one another without a technically precise or scientific language so long as there is an agreed upon meaning of words in a language community.Update 9/25/17:My conclusion is that there is a common syntactical structure to language that is true independent to individual learning, but this does not prove innateness or that language use is an instinct any more than the behavior involved. It’s an important distinction conceptually as going back to John Locke that just because a truth may be a priori or reached by logical necessity by virtue of its structure or definition does not make such a truth innate in the mind. The truths of math and logic are not due to human psychology but are true on their own analytically. The same goes for the structure of language and rules involved. They aren’t inherited any more than math or logic is inherited. They are discovered by us but they not just there in our heads. That explains nothing but infers more to be explained. Language is learned according to our physical abilities and operates according to syntactical rules while the semantic meaning is in a language community of reinforcement. All an instinct is is an unconditioned physical response to stimuli. Certainly our physical use of language evolved but it was for certain definite conditions, eliciting responses from the social environment, the environment in general. An infant’s crying is the language instinct which if not responded to as we can see with the horrific Harlow experiments does not lead to language development but decreased chance of survival, death. Those aspects of the body as coded genetically (and epigenetically perhaps) which aided in eliciting environmental responses which increased fitness to reproduction in past environments are what is inherited but not the behavior itself which is what language is. In hindsight we find as with reality itself a coded structure and regularities in the uses of language, but as with logic and math such a structure holds true without the existence of human “minds” or behavior which are contingent on the selecting environment.

I'm just about at page 300, but wanted to start working on the review ahead of the end.Look, I know that I'm no linguist. I started learning French about 6 months ago and am fascinated by the differences in languages and the generally gloomy prospects for adult language learners. Why, I wondered, are adults so convinced that they can't learn a language like a child can?I have my own pet hypotheses on this question, and they're somewhat more practical than Pinker's hypothesis. Mine basically involves how much time, desire, and willing partners one has to learn from as an adult versus as a child, but people confidently tell me that "there's more to it than that." I'm trying to be open-minded to well-researched points of view that don't match mine...but so far I'm extremely distrustful of many of the conclusions in this book. To the degree that a non-fiction book of this type is about imparting new, relevant information to the reader, I believe that valid doubts about the logic and conclusions presented in this book are valid reasons to deduct stars in the rating, even though I think it is very engagingly-written.First I have to thank Mr. Pinker for debunking early and forcefully the nonsense belief that we "think" in our mother tongues, or that our thoughts are constrained by the languages we know. This idea has always been completely absurd, but I think lots of people in their desire to know deep insights about human nature have uncritically adopted it without thinking it through. If you "think" in your mother tongue, then you couldn't think about things that you didn't know the words for. How would you learn a new word at all? The very fact that we often struggle mid-sentence to find the right word, or we forget the names for things, is proof that we have thoughts that are not expressed in words in our brains. A bit of common sense, people. Come on!But moving on to the major theme of the book, Chomsky's Universal Grammar and the stunning precociousness of young children when it comes specifically to language skills, I have grave doubts about the conclusions on offer.And it's only right that I admit that I have not read many of the relevant studies, did not perform much linguistic coursework in college (though I did do some), and my doubts are essentially just intuitions informed by my struggles to learn Latin in high school, a bit of Russian in college, and French right now. That is, my intuitions are scientifically moot.But I think recent doubt cast over the research methods and findings of many of the landmark studies in the "soft-sciences" of psychology, sociology, etc. leave a bit of an opening for questioning first of all just how valid and significant the cited research in the book is, and then there are the numerous soft spots in the line of reasoning that leads from "3-year-olds are pretty good at speaking" to "humans have an innate sense of grammar that assists their learning as children (but presumably not as adults.)"My complaint is mostly that Pinker seems to be eager to jump from suggestive results in studies to provocative conclusions without examining potential alternate explanations beyond a cursory dismissal of the alternatives that immediately jump to mind. In fact, as far as it has been presented at this point in the book, Chomsky's "poverty of the stimulus" argument could largely be called "cursory dismissal of obvious alternatives."For example, there is the argument that children couldn't have learned to call a fictional monster that eats a certain kind of rodent a "mice-eater" when it eats mice, but a "rat-eater" when it eats rats. It's used throughout the book to remind us of a seeming intuition that children have, wherein they correctly guess that a monster is a "mice-eater" despite lacking an example like "rats-eater" to go off of as an example to extrapolate from. After all, a "rat-eater" eats rats and a "mice-eater" eats mice, but there is no such construction as a "rats-eater." But I have serious reservations about this example and line of reasoning, even if the results of the study that support it are 100% as presented by Pinker. First of all, as a native English speaker with my own intuition about how to create heretofore unseen constructions like "rat-eater" or "squirrel-eater," etc., I have to say that "mice-eater" doesn't even strike my ear as sounding correct, which kind of dashes the impact that this example is supposed to have. Now I may be wrong about my interpretation, and perhaps "mice-eater" is better than "mouse-eater", which is my preferred form, but I think the fact that a native American English speaker has some questions over the more correct form is a bit of a fly in the ointment anyway. To me, a "mice-eater" seems to imply that the monster eats mice by the handful, whereas a "mouse-eater" eats mice one at a time. In which case "rat-eater" would be correct because probably it's only eating one rat at a time, but maybe a monster could eat a whole handful of mice at a time. I guess I'm just being charitable here, though--to me "mouse-eater" sounds better in either case.Lots of these "poverty of the stimulus" arguments propping up Pinker's/Chomsky's conclusions seem pretty weak to me. I think I read an article a long time ago that characterized "poverty of the stimulus" as an argument from "poverty of the imagination," and that feels accurate. I'm already writing a long review so I'll limit myself to one example--the oft-used "Don't giggle me!" mistake that children make. It is argued that since no adult would have said "He giggled me" or "Don't giggle me" to a child, the child lacks a stimulus to create this kind of phrase. Therefore, the child is overgeneralizing a grammar rule that they have learned. For example, you can say "I'm burning" and "He burns me," but for some reason "I'm giggling" does not correspond to "He giggles me." This example is presumably significant because it goes to show that children's "mistakes" tend to be hyper-grammatical, and the real rule that we're faulting them for missing is an exception or is in some cases ungrammatical, and they fail because they are doing the grammatical thing. In essence, this example shows that even many counterexamples to children's grammatical abilities are in fact examples of how grammatically-inclined they are.Now I don't disagree that the child is overgeneralizing, but I am interested in the dispute about whether the child is really in possession of the knowledge of a grammar rule, and to what extent acquiring such a "grammar rule" is significant. It's significant to Pinker and Chomsky because they posit that children have an innate capacity to acquire grammar rules, but for an adult language learner like me, I'm quite suspicious. By any measure, I am acquiring more correct French more quickly than a child does despite not being immersed like a child is, and many committed language learners have similar experiences (though many don't.) Of course, eventually children pass up adult language learners, but this almost certainly has to do with more available time to practice, more indulgence from practice partners, a compulsion to learn more to keep pace with peers and in academics, and a longer time-horizon to become native-like speakers. So I'm suspicious of the "child's innate capacity for grammar" idea in the first place, and when I see it propped up on wobbly legs like "poverty of stimulus," I want to kick at those legs and see if they hold.I see a number of problems with the logic chain between "He giggled me" and the endpoint of "Children have an innate capacity to acquire grammar." I don't mean to say that Pinker says "He giggled me" implies a language instinct, but it is an example marshaled in support of the poverty of the stimulus argument that underlies the language instinct. So is "he giggled me" a significant example of a child using a grammar rule that they could not have learned from their environment? My contention is that although this is a valid example of experimenting with a form that the child has never heard directly based on intuition from other things that a child has heard and said, it doesn't seem significant to me. It's significant to Pinker and Chomsky specifically because they look at language in a certain grammatical way, wherein it is constructed according to combinatorial rules of construction. But is that a true understanding of language? Or is it a potential misunderstanding? For example, Pinker says that the child is generalizing from "It burned" -> "He burned it" to "He giggled" -> "She giggled him." But is this really the way it happened? Or is it possible that the child mistakenly thinks that every verb has both a transitive and intransitive entry in the dictionary? The fact that a child might not make the mistake with certain other intransitive verbs (verbs that don't take a direct object) may be due more to the lack of opportunity to make those errors due to what the words mean. Maybe a child would also make the mistake of saying "The cat got" instead of "the cat got something," except that "got" doesn't really make any sense without a direct object, even to a child, but "giggle" does make a kind of sense even when it does have a direct object. Maybe if you asked a child "Who got the ice cream?" he might say "I got!" instead of "I got it!" I don't know. But nevertheless, it's not impossible to think of alternate explanations for why a child might try "She giggled him." Maybe the child was just venturing a guess and didn't feel confident in what they were saying anyway. Maybe the child had a feeling that it was incorrect to use "giggle" that way, but they weren't sure of the correct construction so they said "She giggled him" anyway. I don't see how it would be possible to dismiss all of the possible reasons that a child might have arrived at this phrase without having an innate knowledge of the grammar, but Pinker and Chomsky do dismiss it.---Part 2.Pinker goes a lot farther in the last 130 pages toward describing why he thinks that there's an innate language module in humans. I'm upgrading my review to four stars from three, because some of my early complaints were addressed late in the book.However, he still undeniably loses a star for his completely absurd defense of the saying "I could care less." He says it's sarcastic, because of the way it's intoned. No way. Pinker is living on Crazy Island. It's way too oblique to be a popular sarcastic saying. For it to be sarcastic, the person being sarcastic has to be sure of how we're going to understand what they say, while at the same time their intonation would indicate that they don't really mean what they're saying. Like "Oh, that's helpful." But "I could care less." is not straightforward enough to easily betray your meaning with your intonation. In fact, if it were said sarcastically, I would expect it to sound more like "I could care less."People who say "I could care less" don't think they're being sarcastic; they usually defend the saying as meaning "I don't care at all, so it's impossible for me to care less." Then they think about what they actually said and say "Oh...I knew that. I was just...just...just slurring my couldn't!" I appreciate Pinker's defenses of certain annoying "rules" of language, like the mandate to not split infinitives (tee-hee) and the mandate to say "Whom do you love?" instead of "Who do you love?" But some things that people say actually are wrong, and "I could care less" is one of them.Also, despite the extra chapters devoted to explaining a possibly evolutionary/biological brain module for language, I still strongly feel that the sum of the arguments presented adds up to significantly less than a proof of the existence of a language instinct that intuitively understands Universal Grammar.And I guess a major complaint I have about this proposition of a language instinct is the very idea of Universal Grammar itself. I haven't ready Chomsky, but...but I just don't think it exists. For example, Pinker described a lot of these rules for the Universal Grammar as conditional: if your language has this one kind of feature, then it doesn't have a different feature, or if your language has this kind of construction in it, then it will also have this kind of construction.That doesn't make much biological sense. Languages, despite similarities, have some extraordinary differences. If all languages were Romance languages, I would be more inclined to accept the Universal Grammar, but does it make sense for a few hundred generations of Western Europeans to be storing an evolutionarily-designed instinct for how to construct tonal, tenseless languages like Mandarin, or agglutinating African languages from the conditional rules applying to tonal and agglutinating languages, according to the rules of Universal Grammar?Something stinks in all of this. Isn't it possible that the explanation is a lot simpler? Maybe based on some shared basic principles of a language that are learned easily enough as children, only certain other kinds of constructions make sense. I wanted to slap Pinker each time he claimed that children recognize rules like "John might fish" and "John loves hot dogs," but never make the mistake of saying "John might hot dogs." There's a simple reason that kids don't make that mistake--what would "John might hot dogs" even mean? Children don't say it because they never have a thought that would potentially be expressed as "John might hot dogs." As for more probable errors, children cutely make them all the time. Imagine that John was at the grill cooking a fish and a child is looking on. It hears someone say out of context "John might fish," meaning that John would consider going fishing later. The child, however, associates the idea of "might fish" with "might cook a fish" or "might eat a fish." Later the child returns and John is grilling a hot dog. Might the child not then say "John might hot dog?" It doesn't sound absurd to me.So I suppose I need more convincing about Universal Grammar. Lots of people say "Yep, it's real, just go read Chomsky," so maybe that's what I need to do. Of course, a lot of people also say "It's a bunch of baloney," and they have read Chomsky, so I don't know.The last few parts about the concept of the Universal People and shared human instinct/learning modules was pretty much all speculation, as far as I can tell. Interesting stuff to think about, but I don't think that we can take a hypothesis like the existence of universal characteristics of all peoples and use that idea as any kind of support for the language instinct hypothesis.

You taught me language, and my profit on ’tIs I know how to curse. The red plague rid youFor learning me your language! - The TempestLanguage is a constant creation of alternative worlds. There are no limits to the shaping powers of words, proclaims the poet. ‘Look,’ says Khlebikov, that virtuoso of extreme statement in his ‘Decrees to the Planet’, ‘the sun obeys my syntax’. Uncertainty of meaning is incipient poetry. In every fixed definition there is obsolescence or failed insight. The teeming plurality of languages enacts the fundamentally creative, ‘counter-factual’ genius and psychic functions of language itself. It embodies a move away from unison and acceptance – the Gregorian homophonic – to the polyphonic, ultimately divergent fascination of manifold specificity. Each different tongue offers its own denial of determinism. ‘The world’, it says, ‘can be other.’ Ambiguity, polysemy, opaqueness, the violation of grammatical and logical sequences, reciprocal incomprehensions, the capacity to lie – these are not pathologies of language but the roots of its genius. Without them the individual and the species would have withered. – George Steiner, After Babel (234-5)I read Steven Pinker’s 
The Language Instinct: How the Mind Creates Language 
because I wanted to know something about Noam Chomsky’s linguistic ideas without making the likely futile attempt to read Chomsky. The book fulfilled this purpose as well as I could wish - except for a few boggy passages it was clearly written, with frequent humor, and the material very well organized. As I reached the end, I became curious about linguistic dissenters from Chomsky and whether these had legitimate scientific arguments or were driven to apostasy by Chomsky’s politics or personality. I briefly toyed with then abandoned the idea of reading Tom Wolfe’s The Kingdom of Speech; it was clear this would have quickly turned into a pure hate-reading experience. I did discover that Wolfe’s main source on anti-Chomsky linguistics is Daniel Everett who, linguistic accomplishments aside, seems pretty interesting as a character. I may eventually read his book Don't Sleep, There are Snakes: Life and Language in the Amazonian Jungle, but for now I was satisfied with this long New Yorker article by John Colapinto. Overview:1. An Instinct to Acquire an Art. The claim that language is an instinctual rather than learned behavior.2. Chatterboxes. The universality of language and the commonalities of the necessary components that make up languages.3. Mentalese. Showing that thought is not dependent on language.4. How Language Works. A description of grammar - Chomsky's theories - how grammar builds meaning.5. Words, Words, Words. Vocabulary; inferred rules governing the building of words (tenses, possessives, compounds).6. The Sounds of Silence. How speech embodies language and affects its structure.7. Talking Heads. How language is understood by the hearer or reader.8. The Tower of Babel. Conjectures about the variety of languages and their origins.9. Baby Born Talking - Describes Heaven. The pattern of infants' language development. Conjectures about how this learning occurs.10. Language Organs and Grammar genes. - The hardware of language - brain, neurons, genes. Interesting on how brain injuries or damage can affect speech ability in very specific grammar-related ways.11. The Big Bang. Contemplates evolutionary paths to language. Mocking accounts of human researchers teaching chimps and gorillas sign language or language-like symbol manipulation. More than once Pinker makes the claim that "natural selection can take skills that are acquired with effort and uncertainty and hardwire them into the brain," (pg. 377) which seems to me indistinguishable from Lamarckism. Unlike Pinker, Chomsky himself seems unwilling to definitely say that language is a result of natural selection. The alternative would seem to be that, given a sufficiently large brain, it "just growed". (Topsy's intuitive regularization of the irregular English verb grow is itself an example of Universal Grammar in action.)12. The Language Mavens. Grammar gurus are, at best, entertainers like Richard Lederer and at worst, scolds like William Safire who, in looking for grammatical "errors" violating arbitrary rules of usage, miss the inventiveness and nuance of nonstandard English and unusual, but grammatical constructions.13. Mind Design. The implications on the brain having an inherited "language module". Opposition to the "blank slate" Standard Social Science Model. A list of characteristics of the "Universal People", human behaviors and practices that exist in all cultures and lands; Pinler's conjecture on what sort of mental "modules" might underlie these characteristics.

I am still on the journey of exploring human nature. This book explains language which is another capacity we take for granted as part of daily life. Thinking of it, It’s really a miracle that I can convey an idea in a Facebook post so that anyone could reconstruct the same idea with all its intricate details in their mind any time they read my words. There are so many questions to unpack and here is my summary of it:  1- Are we born with language skills or do we learn them from society?Up until Noam Chomsky’s universal grammar revolution, behaviourism was the dominant theory on linguistics, that’s people learn behaviours (including language) from society and are not born with them like physical features. Chomsky challenged that view and, supported by significant evidence from neuroscience, that we are born with language centers in our brain that has universal grammar skills and when we learn a specific language, say English, we only train those brain regions to the parameters specific to English such as the Subject Verb Object-SVO structure used in English . Chomsky and his friends spent their career synthesizing hundreds of languages from all corners of the planet to arrive to those universal grammar rules, such as the concepts of noun phrases, verb phrases, recursive structures e.g., “The boy’s shirt’s button” and found them in all languages. Furthermore, neuroscience showed that different levels of damage to brain regions such as the Broca and Wernicke areas have specific effects, e.g., inability to identify names in general or even specific categories of names such as fruits or colours. Chomsky’s universal grammar is the current model of understanding language, behaviourism is completely ruled out. 2-How did language skills evolve?Thousands of modern human languages developed and changed independently across the globe, however the universal language skills we are born with is believed to have passed down to Homo Sapiens from their Homo Erectus or even older ancestors. We can’t know what was homo erectus language like compared to, say modern English, but we know for sure that no other living species on this planet have our highly complex language organ like no other species other than elephants have their sophisticated trunk organ. Language gave early hunters a great advantage to communicate military and hunting plans, therefore, it’s not hard to imagine why the ruthless force of natural selection favoured it. It’s also believed we were pushed to learn it very early in our lives, because the earlier children learned language, the sooner they would understand their mom’s warnings from the close by sabretooth, hence, the higher their chances to survive and re-produce 3-How are languages different?While technology and science enabled the industrial revolution and the great rise of European political power in the past 500 years, European languages are by no means the most advanced. In fact, some of the languages found in modern day hunter gatherer tribes are so complex it would put English and other common languages to shame! An example of that is the Kivunjo language spoken by less than a million people in Africa has verbs with seven possible prefixes and suffixes, two moods, and fourteen tenses; the verb agrees with its subject, its object, and its benefactive nouns, each of which comes in sixteen genders! I thought Arabic is a sophisticated language, but compared to Kivunjo it’s a child’s play! 4-How does language change?Language change significantly, 1000 years old English could hardly be recognized as the language we speak today. It started in Germanic tribes then had strong Latin and French influences, followed by natural tendencies to simplify, for example. The past tense of verbs used to follow an old model of Take, took. Fight, fought, drive, drove. But the auxiliary ‘did’ transformed to ‘ed’ was an easier way to create past tense versions, e.g., created, played. However, the most common irregular verbs remained in language as a fossil of the old grammar. The same exists in Arabic, where an old complex pluralization grammar “takseer” still lingers besides the easier and more standardized “Mozakkar salem and Moaanath Salem” format. 5-What are the societal implications of linguistic studies?Linguists discovered that languages from India to Europe and several places in between share many common words, such as “mother”, “brother”, etc which led them to believe that early humans who spread eastward to India and Northwards to Europe shared an old common language called the Indo-European language. European racist movements claimed that this language originated in Europe in what’s commonly known as the Arian race. They claim that some Arian tribes migrated to the south spreading the language, however, in the process, they interbred with locals and lost their “Arian purity”. That’s why racist cultures in Nazi Germany and American south banned interracial marriages. Needless to say, this is all bogus, however, racist ideologies are still alive and well in 2018. Highly recommended.

Comrades, this book made me a Chomskyite. No, no, no, not politically, OBVS, but linguistically. I read Chomsky many years ago, and wasn't quite convinced, somewhat under the influence of eg George Steiner.New readers start here: Chomsky said, essentially, that language was innate, and had what he called a deep structure, common to all human languages. Children have a universal grammar, which is hardwired into their brains before birth, so they do not learn language from others but develop it themselves. This is why children who have just started talking say things like "I goed" instead of "I went" - words they have never heard, but have extrapolated from their pre-verbal grammar. My daughter, aged two, when urged "Quickly!", often replied "I am quickling". Anyway, I wasn't totally convinced, back then, and was in any case prejudiced against Chomsky because, like too many USian academics, he is a monoglot - but Pinker has done it now. It's certainly clear that children are not language tabulae rasae.Along the way, Pinker points out the Great Eskimo Language Hoax (that there are many words for snow) - in fact the languages of that region typically have fewer words for snow than English does - which hoax is still widely believed; largely I think because people want it to be true. Pinker is also educational and clear. He tells us straight, for instance, that a creole is the language that results when children make a pidgin their native language. All languages are created by children, and they do it by creating a grammar for the words they use. This would invalidate Orwell's Newspeak, as children would creolise it within a generation.Thoughts are not words, Pinker informs us. If they were, how could more than one thought be expressed by a single word? Or vice versa?This book treats of cognitive psychology, and is often complex. I confess to reading the complex accounts of experiments and studies in speech and thought quite quickly, not stopping to study and consider them as I would have to do if I were reading this book in an academic setting.Pinker points out that what he calls "language mavens", but which he means prescriptive pedants (people who write to newspapers saying that a preposition is something with which a sentence should never be ended) choose their examples of abominable English from sources like welfare applications, insurance claims, and student papers; in all of these the writers are trying to convince, and to make a good impression, and are only rarely using language that is natural to them. And yes, I know how long that sentence just was.This is not a crowd-pleaser, or a particularly easy read. Pinker's own passions do show through, at times entertainingly: he hates relativism, he says "more than I hate anything, excepting, maybe, fiberglass powerboats", and it is a quirkily amusing read in many places without ever being arch or droll.This is a book for anyone interested in language - and we all, in our own ways, are.

Steven Pinker propounds that language isn't just a social construction, acquired by children through mere imitations of sounds in a conversation of two adults. Language is, as Chomsky partially put it, an innate mechanism of the mind. Although Pinker, conceding that Chomsky influenced his views on language, still differs with him on Universal Grammar. How could the mind have evolved without the endowment of natural selection? This investigates more than just a biological claims of language; rather, it delves into intricate compartments of language in morphology, phonology, grammar, syntax, cognitive abilities and speech perception, first language acquisition and the book ends how the mind produces language, which is brief. Of course it is a misunderstanding that thought is superseded by language, it is vice versa; thought supersedes language. And, Pinker, having touched on linguistic determinism in several accounts, illustrated that it's actually symbols, gestures and conventionalized semantics that propel language, through thought, to be produced. This is discussed in great detail in How the Mind Works and his advocacy of the Computational Theory of Mind, and Conceptual Semantics in The Stuff of Thought. What I found intriguing about this book, although not as much as the Stuff of Though, is his redundant content. Pinker at times seems to perpetuate consistent arguments about language, cognition and psychology, which is inherently good from my point of view. However, having read The Blank Slate, The Stuff of Thought, How the Mind Works (60% of it) and the Language Instinct. I've noticed a certain pattern of cross-over references to language, mind, culture and human nature, as if each book, generally, leads to the next one. The Language Instinct, with all its glory, is aimed at the general public, who may or may haven't studied linguistics. I studied linguistics at university and did some extensive reading about it before reading this book. I'd say much of what the book says is, for me at least, repeated. But that's not a bad thing. I recommend this however to those who haven't studied a thing about linguistics for its friendly writing style and brimming knowledge that it's got not only on language, but also on the human condition

"The Language Instinct" is not an easy read, but it is a fascinating one. Steven Pinker describes in detail the idea that language acquisition is an instinct of the human mind. His thesis is based on Chomsky's research and evolutionary psychology. First of all, Pinker is adamant in his dismissal of the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis - the idea that language we speak shapes the way in which we perceive the world. The Sapir-Whorf hypothesis is often illustrated by the hundreds of words Eskimos supposedly have for snow- in fact, Pinker points out, they have no more than dozen "but by such standards English would not be far behind: snow, sleet, slush, blizzard....". Pinker believes that the studies which suggest that our language shapes our perception of the worlds are at times grossly exaggerated, and at times improperly conducted and woefully inadequate. His own suggestion is that we perceive the world with something he calls "mentalese": "people do not think in English or Chinse or apache; they think in a language of thought". In a way, Pinker's description of mentalese takes us back to the James Joyce vs Virginia Woolf debate: do people think in words or do they think with the use of images?Pinker's suggestion of mentalese introduces his general attack on linguistic relativism. His hypothesis that human beings all share a basic language instinct is linked to inherent belief a single structure of the human mind which is the same for all mankind. The book is particularly interesting in its exploration of language acquisition in children. Not many people are aware that: "A newborn has a vocal tract like a nonhuman mammal (...) making it anatomically possible to drink and breathe at the same time. By three months the larynx has descended deep into the throat, opening up the cavity behind the tongue to move forwards and backwards and produce the variety of vowel sounds used by adults."My one slight problem with the book is Pinker's dismissive attitude towards language learning in adults. His patronising attitude towards the English of Conrad, Nabokov and others seems to indicate that it is useless to learn any new language past the age of seven (which is the acquisition window for being able to become a native speaker). He seems to comfortably ignore the fact that the two people he mentions above are two of the best writers in the English language, despite their struggles with accents and unwillingness to give live interviews. There are a great many aspects of "The Language Instinct" that I did not manage to touch upon in this short review- suffice it to say, it is a very informative read for anyone with the slightest interest in linguistics.

As I am often wont to do, I took too big a bite in reading this book.Unless you’re a serious grammarian or have some sort of background in linguistics, some of the concepts may be inaccessibly to you.I still learned plenty though, and more than anything else, love Pinker’s caustic attitude and contrarian personality.         Here are 2 examples;"One of the unifying threads will be that complete cultural relativism makes anthropologists far more credulous of almost any absurdity than almost any ordinary person would be, equipped only with common sense. In fact, a lot of this nonsense is part of the standard intellectual equipment of every educated social scientist, providing a permanent obstacle to balanced reasoning about various psychological and social phenomena. I figure it will make me permanently unemployable, so I am not aiming to finish it any time soon."“With a few exceptions… mainstream American Linguists have left the field entirely to the Mavens.
