I'm a linguistics student and when people know a little bit about linguistics, but not a whole lot about it, they sometimes ask me if I have read any Steven Pinker.Until now, I hadn't, so I always said "No, but I've heard of him!"Anyway, The Language Instinct isn't a bad book, but I think it has some issues.It's too technical for many laypeople to read easily, but doesn't contain anything that someone with a bachelor's degree in Linguistics wouldn't already have learned in class. Literally, almost no new information was imparted to me by reading this book--which is a shame because other than a general brush up on stuff I've learned the last few years, it was kind of a waste of my time. I was really hoping for more and I don't know why I thought I would get it.If you've taken phonology, syntax, semantics, first language acquisition, and second language acquisition, as I have, you've learned this stuff already! And heard many of the exact same examples Pinker uses in the text! And also, read many, if not most, of the studies he cites! And wondered why you bothered reading The Language Instinct!So that was a bummer. I fully admit to HEAVILY skimming the last three chapters because I was, understandably, pretty bored. At the same time though, I can't imagine handing this book to a non-linguistics-student friend and honestly believing that that friend would still let me recommend them books afterward--it feels to technical for people who don't want to be linguists but not all that helpful for someone who might be on their way to becoming one. Who is this book for?It's just a really weird space for a popular science book to sit in.Also, Pinker kind of badmouths Carl Sagan a little--not too seriously, it felt like more of a misreading--but it offended my Sagan-loving sensibilities while I was already kind of over this book. It felt like the last straw.

This book is great, okay. I usually am super nitpicky in my reviews but you win Pinker, you've written a great book. Of course it helps that I'm probably the exact target audience (so take this review as you will).tldr; have you ever wondered about language? Or maybe you haven't but now you're curious - this book will give you a the rundown of everything there is to know at a very readable, friendly, introductory level. Yes, there are concepts you might not understand, but this book should propel you to do more research/reading if you're interested in a specific part/topic and instigate that language love and curiosity.At least it did for me.Okay, I might have 'cheated' a little since this is basically what my major (Cognitive Science) back in college was about. I had context in almost all the topics he covered, but it was great to get another perspective as well as dive a little deeper on the English language. Oh, note, this book is mainly about the English language. He does touch a little on other languages when doing comparisons but I don't think he has the background (and he acknowledges this) on languages such as Chinese to do a in-depth analysis on that. It was also refreshing to have an author acknowledge things he did not know. In the end, he presents a few pages on things that changed sine he wrote the book - ie. theories that were disproved or veered off since then. It made the book seem much more conversational instead of a dry textbook full of facts type of feel.I feel like if you don't have any background, it might be a little tricky to understand (as I see from the other reviews on here). But I do urge you then to just find the sections you're interested in! Since the book covers a ranger a topics from grammar (love) to biology to artificial intelligence (also a real interesting section considering this was published in 1994). It serves a great intro to this crazy world of human language and cognition and Pinker does make the effort to make it as readable and enjoyable (a lot of jokes) as possible.

The best book that I have come across, on the topic of linguistics, so far. This book deals mostly with the syntactic aspects of language and the possible cognitive mechanisms that are critical for language acquisition and understanding in humans. There are 2 popular schools of thoughts regarding this. The first, championed by the likes of Noam Chomsky, believes that every human possesses something called a 'universal, generative grammar', which is an innate mental framework that underlies any language and is the mechanism responsible for learning languages. The other school of thought, that of Linguistic Relativity which was championed by the likes of Sapir-Whorf, believes that language learning isn't something that can be associated with any distinct internal machinery and is something that must be taught and is something that has the ability to affect our thoughts and actions.Professor Pinker clearly belongs to the former group but unlike Chomsky, who took a purely analytical approach to linguistics, he also improves upon the validity of the universal grammar theory by providing experimental evidence from his own resesrch into cognitve mechanisms of language learning and often, language therapy.In addition to syntax, topics on phonology and morphology are also discussed in separate chapters and make for a fairly complete reading of the subject. The content is extremely accessible and comes with an extensive bibliography for those interested in exploring certain topics at greater depths.

This was the sole book on language or linguistics in the bookstore, and I wanted a book on that topic, so I bought it, though I didn't really want to. I'm not a scientist or particularly interested in learning about science, but I do respect it, and the only other encounters I've had with evolutionary psychology made me feel the field was incredibly lame at best, as in no-science-involved-here. Apparently I've had a poor sampling (probably because the stuff I read generally isn't written by scientists). I put down this book feeling like I understand evolution and natural selection better than before, and appreciating, if not fully understanding, how thought and language may be connected to those processes. I left thinking he knows what he's talking about, and even that maybe, one day, I'll have to follow up and read more on the topic. Big win, Pinker! But more importantly for me is I learned so much about how language works in the mind - I was fascinated by his explanation of the Walkmen/Walkmans dilemma, for example, and by the experiments that reveal to us how children analyze language use. This book covered so much ground! It hits that sweet spot of being written for a popular audience as a survey of a large academic field, without being too informal or gimmicky, yet also not being stiff and dry. And despite the amount of STUFF, it traveled at an appropriate pace and was well-organized.Now, having stated my admiration and appreciation for what he wrote, I would like to make a few critical notes.First, having recently discovered that a friend of mine is an "aphantasiac" and does not have a mind's eye/ear/empirical sense, I do question his concept of "mentalese", or at least what I understand him to be saying. I know myself that sometimes my thoughts DO present themselves in English.Second, while I'm not a scientist, I am a careful reader, so I can say that Pinker's argumentation is not as watertight as he'd like it to be. He occasionally forgets what he's arguing for: for example, he's not worried about losing the word "whom" because descriptivism, but "whom" is stupid in the first place and "who" should be prescribed as the better option. What? Sometimes he even contradicts himself: Our larynx dropped because of the evolutionary advantage that language gave us. But neanderthals might have used a perfectly functional language despite undropped larynges. Third, I did finally get lost in the last two or three pages. Too many high-level ideas packed into too few words to follow or understand the point. Way to end with a bang?Fourth, he has a surprising number of typos and plain mistakes that I'm surprised weren't fixed by the editor in reprints - for example, he once refers to a "quarter-twist" as able to correct a half-twist.But while I may have questions and disagreements with this book, I have to give it to Pinker for translating something so broad and deep and detailed into something so manageable for a lay reader. I may have bought it because I had no other options, but this is one that'll stay on my shelf for a very long time.

An oldie but a goodie.I've taken a break half way through (interrupted by a nostalgic binge of Harry Potter audiobooks) and so now have forgotten what Pinker talked about in the first half. I'm sure something has seeped in anyway and will usefully re-emerge at some point. I found it amusing how after a paragraph of polished academic writing Pinker will suddenly make a witty comment or say something colloquial or slang-y. I hope I too will some day reach the level of self-confidence and authority to refute an argument with something similar to: "To this I say: maven, shmaven." (This was followed up with more reasoning, but appreciate the nerve!)The last chapter was naturally of most interest to me (evolutionary psychology, modularity debate) and pulled some interesting references out of it. Overall, I skimmed some parts, just because I am already familiar with the arguments or the studies, but there was always some interesting opinion or conclusion, so the book is still enjoyable if you have some background in the area. Probably gonna be mindblowingly cool in places if you did not study any cognitive psychology or linguistics or something similar. (Although may be a little dry if you get too hung up on auxilaries and predicates and noun phrases moving about in such and such way. A few Wikipedia articles can probably help here for the likes of me who don't know much about grammar terms).

I’m going to struggle reviewing this book simply for the fact when I purchased it I was misinformed as to what it was based upon.I was looking for a book to help with foreign language learning and while this was slightly helpful it wasn’t really what I was looking for. However after reading this I can’t help but feel there were many things about my own language and how we take to learning it which was really useful information to know and very interesting also.It’s was strange to notice all the misconceptions surrounding the English language and could tell that Steven Pinker felt very strongly opposed to what some linguists believe is the correct use of speech and how that may well be entirely incorrect.The fact that as species we have an instinct to naturally learn the language of our native tongue or that in which we are raised makes us completely unique to all other animals.What I also found intriguing was the fact of how some people could struggle to express words in their speech but were still able to read and write to an advanced level. I believe he mentioned a famous Polish writer who’s name I can’t remember, but he quoted him saying that his writing was excellent yet when he spoke it was like that of a 10 year old due to English not being his first language.Overall it was a good book even though it wasn’t exactly what I was looking for but if it’s a topic of real interest to you I’d highly recommend it.

I first started reading this book during a layover in an airport, surrounded by a language I did not speak. It was in that context that I dived head-first into Steven Pinker's book outlining the case for an intrinsic instinct underlying human language. Pinker provides a significant amount of detail to keep a non-linguist (and non-neuroscientist) in context with the arguments, as well as thoroughly entertained. Several passages are dedicated to wrestling with common criticisms of modern english, and prescriptivism more generally, all of which are surprisingly fun to read even if they're a bit of a branch off the central argument of the book. Previously I'd never put much thought into language as a marvelous neurological feat, outside perhaps the occasional polyglot, so the central essence of this book was all quite new to me. I'll also admit I'd been awed by the signing apes and other animals-with-language that have made the news over the years, the self-same ones that Pinker thoroughly explains away. All said, I thoroughly enjoyed both the entertaining anecdotes and more contagious arguments - both have made me more thoughtful about the things people say and the machinery that makes "saying" even possible. I'd recommend this book highly to anyone curious about language, brains, development, and the quirks of English in particular.

Ignore the weird cover. I read this because my linguistics friends recommended it and it gives you (as far as I know!) a good introduction to the field. My favourite point he makes is that humans' language is just a special skill like bats' sonar.I learned some cool things, including how it's possible to do experiments with babies (by checking when they look surprised/pay attention). He also goes into other topics like evolutionary theory, which I knew less about than I realised. For me, it's hard to assess how biased it is - he's pushing his theory of a language instinct and I'm not sure how much of the book is accepted orthodoxy and how much argument.It took me about two months to read this book, reading a chapter at a time - in true Pinker style (from what my friend who read Blank Slate told me) it's pretty dense. He's also a massive fans of examples (I think a typical linguistics trait) and goes a bit OTT on them - feel free to skip the lists! My least favourite chapter was probably where he was just slating "Language Mavens" (bad language columnists) who slate other people for bad grammar.

20% of this was utterly fascinating. It made me think about language, biology, evolution, psychology and sociology in new ways. The other 80% was padding out an essay to make the word count. Perhaps that's because I'm more interested in certain aspects of linguistics? Perhaps it's because I listened to the audiobook? Perhaps it's even because these ideas have been around for so long that they've been absorbed in the public conscience and no longer need such in-depth defence and justification? But I'm pretty sure had I had a physical copy I could have skim-read a decent portion of most of the chapters without leaving too much of the understanding behind. That said, sections of it were worth suffering the rest for. One day I'll probably get a copy to stick post-it notes in and refer back to, but also this is supposed to be a book for the general public and there are bits that I would have had to go away and google if I hadn't already done a very basic linguistics course. It's not an introduction; don't start here unless you've already studied language in some capacity. Don't expect it to be up-to-date. But it's a fascinating reference point.

Very interesting book, regardless of who you are, as someone who enjoys learning foreign languages I should admit that this changed my view a bit on the purpose of it and will leave me thinking on my approaches to them.-The main argument the book makes is that language develops naturally during childhood, it's further discussed that learning a language later in life can't be compared to learning the language as your mother tongue, as the "grammar" developed in childhood is the closest to the real language.-On the other hand, the book claims that the "rule" that language can't be considered correct, once it has taken a dialect, is nonsense. Once you can see the layer beneath the "mistakes" people make by using their way of speaking, and that the main purpose is getting the right message across, language becomes more enjoyable. This gives me confidence in not focussing on perfection too much in learning my target language, but rather seeing the purpose as: Being able to understand, and to communicate, with or without mistakes.

Dog bites man. - Simple. Man bites dog. - Newsworthy. Got it. I am not a fan of Mr Pinker's ideas. The existence of the language instinct to a certain extent, for example. Nor I appreciate his way of presenting them. It leaves me sad when scientists accuse other scientists of having different points of view. However, I find him brave as there aren't many linguists who embrace the grammatical reality instead of purifying all those who err through the test of hell fire. I expected the book to be more about neuro- and less about linguistics. There was a whole chapter dedicated to how the brain processes language. The topics of all the others were spread across the area of language and the focus was somewhat blurred. Generally, it was refreshing to scan through the book purely out of interest and without the pressure of the necessity to pass the Linguistics exam at Uni.

Throughout the entire book, the author has one goal of trying to convince us that language is actually a human instinct. Steven Pinker provides viewpoints from different field experts- linguists, psychologists, anthropologists, and various studies. He provides various possibilities and theories that prevail in the field and then provides arguments to convince us that language is in fact an instinct to us humans.Whether or not anyone is convinced by this book that language is an instinct, they would surely end up appreciating the ingenuity of the human brain behind language perception. I found the sections about speech perception and parsing very interesting. Overall, this book gave me a good introduction to how a linguist views language. But, there were many parts of the book where it felt like there was too much technical detail for a reader who is not from this field.

Not what I expected. Only the first chapter I found interesting in a philosophical way. The rest is really about the "How" of the subtitle. He goes into nitty-gritty detail about why for example the "nitty" comes before the "gritty", how letters build words, pronounced in specific ways in phonemes, building sentences. Another chapter is his own opinion on how we should me more flexible in grammar rules, with plenty of his personal frustrations. The only take-away was the fresh perspective he offered with reference to the animal kingdom: People talk like spiders spin a web. Short, not the book I wanted to read.

Blatant propaganda. Language Is A Virus From Outer Space. Language is the first and last conspiracy. It gave us the works of Shakespeare, but what about the debit column? After all, it is language that brings Philip Schofield into being. Is it worth it? The claim that anything 'comes naturally' is the salesman's last ditch effort. Given the supposed size of the universe, Language, like life itself seems vanishingly uncommon. Precedent is instructive but not absolute, nor is it universally binding. Origin and ultimate purpose remain unknown - your guess is as good as mine, or the exalted Pinker.

Pinker has a dry wit, is opinionated and intelligent. (He reminds me of Bill Bryson). The cover of this book doesn't do justice to the content and research. At times I was completely lost as to what he was trying to explain, but the analogies are brilliant and you will definitely learn something and laugh along the way. His focus is the belief that our brains have the biological makeup to develop language spontaneously, without conscious effort or formal instruction. I would recommend it to linguistic enthusiasts.

A solid work. Pinker writes lucidly, accessible, always plainly and often in a witty manner. He covers most linguistic-adjacent sciences - the nuero-linguistic, as well as the psyco-, the computo-, the evolutionary biologico-, historico-, and plenty others. Sometimes overly pedantic, but the parts you dont like you can often skip, so i cant say it leads to a significant worsening of the experience. Would recommend to any general pop-science reader and especially those into linguistics or evolutionary psychology.

The writing’s accessible to anyone, the topic starts to get niche around this level, but I loved it. I love that Pinker went to the effort of critiquing Whorf (just elements of the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis), because no one does that, but I think he’s only partly right at best. A better defense of language as perception-primer should stick to dialects and jargons of a single language to cut back on some of the extra historical/semantic variables.I was not familiar with the depth-first vs. breadth-first parsing debate, that was interesting.

A good overview of linguistics in the first six chapters. Skim over the 90s-era computing and genetics. Pinker also seems to believe that selection acting alone and directly on the language-associated regions of the brain is solely responsible for the evolution of language acquisition. His arguments would be better supported by a more balanced view of how both adaptive and nonadaptive processes might have contributed to the evolution of language. One plus: Pinker is a good writer.

I gave this book 3.5 stars. I have meant to read this for a long time, and I waited so long that some of the concepts are outdated. For example, the author states that computers cannot yet "understand" human speech well enough to transcribe it. That probably was true in the late 1990s. A lot of the concepts in the book are pretty complex; however there is much that is fascinating, and Pinker takes a technical subject and often discusses it in very down to earth (and often humorous) terms.

Review: Great analysis of how people create and manage language. Funny at times, and very insightful. Favorite Quote: "It is not that I doubt that language evolved only once", one of the assumptions behind the search for the ultimate mother tongue. It's just that one can trace words back only so far. It is like the man who claimed to be selling Abraham Lincoln's ax - he explained that over the years the head had to be replaced twice and the handle three times."

My interest in Cognitive Science (Analytics) and being surrounded by linguist friends made me to read this book. This fascinating book by Steven Pinker focuses on language acquisition and how it is an instinct. Compelling arguments and supporting examples help to understand the concepts clearly. Further, this book helps one to understand why despite the advancements in technology, we haven't achieved 100 per cent in Natural Language Processing for Robots or Computer Machines!

Although Pinker annoys me as a person, this book is a really, really good intro to linguistics (and I say this with my "PhD in linguistics" hat on). It is a lovely intro to the concept of, and arguments for, universal grammar, and I particularly enjoyed the discussions of the evolution and biological, basis of language - what a lovely, tempered approach. If you wanted an engaging, accurate pop science language book? This is your book.

You know how sometimes the earliest works by great bands are their best? I sometimes feel the same way about authors."The Language Instinct" was one of Steven Pinker's first (the first?) books, and ranks as my favorite. A great example of a book on an area, written by an expert who conveys their love and enthusiasm for the subject. On my shortlist of favorite science / evolutionary psychology books of all time.

I quite liked a lot of this, but the first half was very challenging to work through. Pinker writes every bit as well as his reputation suggests, but unfortunately proving the existence of a language instinct requires pages and pages of grammatical proofs. If, like me, your application of grammatical rules is done pretty much by feel, you may struggle with this as well. In any case, I learned a lot about language and the functioning of the mind... but I'm glad there's no final exam.3.5/5

In the prologue to the book, Pinker says that he has never met anyone who wasn't interested in language at least to some extent. Regardless of whether that is true or not, I found it a fascinating book! His style is amiable and easy to understand. Being someone interested in language, I would have this book is more centred on linguistics; there is a good dose of grammar analysis, but in reality it's much more about natural selection, evolution and hereditary/non-hereditary characteristics.

It’s such a hard book to chew as leisure reading, which clearly reminds me what a small English vocabulary I have. 4 star given to the sheer vast information, enlightening analogies in its explanations. Only recommended to those interested in this subject of language, human’s ability of learning, or as the book says in the end, evolutionary psychology Might be better to read on kindle to look up words and take notes (of where you actually understands)

A pleasure to read. I found some passages a bit superfluous and repetitive but overall, the book is very skilfully written. While psycholinguistics is an incredibly interesting field, it can easily get a bit dense.Here, Pinker's writing style really comes to the rescue. It has both the ingenuity and precision of great writing. The end result is a text that really helps you grasp the concepts, all while having a very pleasing flow

A perfect example of "never judge a book by its cover". On the cover, it says "How the mind creates language" but you won't learn anything about it. Every chapter starts with a hypothesis or a question, but it's neither proved nor answered through the chapter. Reading only the first three chapters would suffice which explain that languages might be an instinct in our genetics and not a 100% cultural phenomenon. No need to spend time on the rest of the book.

I recommend using critical thinking while reading this book.I listened to the blinks only so I may not have gotten the nuances but at least the blinkist version did not mention any conclusive arguments but only speculations and was even bringing up a contradicting case study.I felt strong enough about this to also do a search for further material and comments with references to scientific studies and stumbled upon Vyvyan Evans, The Language Myth: Why Language Is Not An Instinct.

'The Language Instinct' by Steve Pinker is an excellent book on linguistics. Dr Pinker demonstrates to the reader the links between linguistics and the Natural Sciences and Maths. This is most obvious through the description of how language is connected to logic, which is a Mathematical concept. All in all, I will definitely recommend this book for people who are interested in linguistics for general knowledge or looking forward to pursuing a degree in linguistics/foreign languages.

Phenomenal book. If you're interested in language as a mere layperson, then this book is for you. Steven Pinker shares his intellect in the most accessible of ways and adds a lot of humor to boot. I will be rereading this book at some point because it is jammed with great information on how the brain works with language and I couldn't get it all the first time. I'm certain will like it as much the second time. Cheers

A very readable book with well-structured discussion of theories and findings. Among all the theses in this book, I find these ones especially intereting: nativism of language/grammar, criticism of Whorfian hypothesis, criticism of language mavens. (I barely remember the history and biology sections in this book.)

I'll need to re-read this - I finally finished it, but it has taken me so long to finally get through it that I don't have a cohesive impression of the book anymore. It *is* a book so crammed full of facts and insights into language that it felt almost overwhelming to read it, especially if I were to try to summarize key points for someone else over watercooler conversation.

Interesting and concise arguments, and an enjoyable read for the most part (last couple of chapters seemed like rants and ramblings, at least to me). I liked it. Makes sense that it focuses so much on the English language in particular, but that chapters in which he focuses on how all languages might have evolved from a single proto-language, was fantastic.

This is a very readable, very comprehensive, overview of the state of linguistics; the examples are both interesting and enlightening, and Pinker is clear what the major debates are and where he stands on them. Long and requires concentration (took me about a year to get through it, reading in short bursts of enthusiasm and then laying it aside for a while), but really repays the attention.

For me here are too much specific English examples, in the second half of book. Meanwhile author already proofed that we all have "the same language for aliens" and common language instinct, no reasons for so long repeating and only one languages examples. In general it's good, 4 stars and recommend to read (you could skip some pages with that boring details).

Quite good for introductory reading since Pinker obviously possess the talent of distilling research results, which are often spiced with interesting examples and anecdotes. That being said, most introductory textbooks of general linguistics will cover the content. Hence this book is more for general readers than academics.

A bit dry in parts, but overall excellent and fascinating. Pretty compelling view of how closely related human languages are despite the impressive variety. Also continues to change my views on how languages evolve and the silliness of clinging too strongly to arbitrary rules.Readability 5. Rating 6.

I am still a bit unsure of what to make of Steven Pinker as an author, after reading two books by him. I feel he could have used less technical language, but overall, found it accessible. I do appreciate the notes sections, where he made corrections and comments on what has changed since the 1st printing. I appreciate the evolutionary psychology approach to the subject also.

Super interesting, and definitely one of my favourite non-fiction books. Well written, clearly argumented, and it stands the test of time pretty well. Not everything he says I find fully believable (e.g. genes encoding for grammar) but language is explained in a most lucid, logical and also entertaining way.Also, I find the Afterword added ~20 years later and the reference list very helpful.

Very dense at times and skips from technical to theoretical and between unrelated topics often, but on the whole absolutely worth the read. I've brought up different concepts from the book in conversation several times within a few months of starting it because it really is eye opening to so much of our everyday lives

A lot of really interesting content. It was particularly interesting to compare to the almost-three-year-old in our house. I want to give it 4 or maybe 5 stars.It also felt like it really, really, really dragged on in many places, so I'm rating based on how I actually feel about having read it.I suspect some material could really use an update today in 2018.

I don't have a real argument for the premise that we are born with the ability for forming language, there are many scientific examples in this book, that's the downfall for me. It could have been more accessible as it is an interesting topic, with some clever wordplay and linguist jokes I could just about understand

This is a good introduction to the core concepts of human language but it fails to deliver an overall argument in my opinion. Maybe it was the audiobook or the speed at which I consumed this or the fact that I knew a lot of the content already but I feel like this is more a book for students rather than interested professionals/scientists who want to hear another person's point of view.

I wasn't sure what to rate this, because there were a lot of parts where the science and stuff was so cool and interesting that I wanted to give it a five, but also parts where the author was so obnoxious that I wanted to give it a one. So here's halfway between that, learned some really cool stuff, wouldn't necessarily read this guy again.

This book is cognitive brain food. Pinker has a powerfull pedagogic way to explain his theories, like when he picks up stuff from earlier chapter in his later ones to make his point clearer and more understood in his complete theory of the language instinct. I will definitely read more of Professor Pinkers books.

Long winded and somewhat dated now in 2020, but I felt that I needed to have read it as a language educator. Pinker provides some great examples, but I often found myself coming up with counter examples and arguments in my head in some of the later chapters. I'm glad that I finally made it through the book after over 5 years of intending to read it.

A great breakdown of how innate/instinctual language is and a fascinating look at universal grammar rules. Pinker's wit and cultural commentary made me LOL in real life. If you have a curious inkling towards linguistics, I highly recommend this book but if you want a list of fun etymologies, this is not for you. (Instead, I'd recommend the podcast History of English or the book Lingo)

The first third of this book gave me a good sense of how little I really knew about language and linguistics. The fact that it was only the first third of the book gave me a good sense for how much interest I have in the topic. :)

Steven Pinker, one of the world’s foremost experts on language and the mind, explores how language works, how we learn it, and how it evolves. He lands on the site of language being a human instinct, birthed by evolution.

A bit on the meh side. Maybe 30% in I decided to get the audio version but fell asleep listening to it several times if memory serves. Sorry, I don't think you'll learn much that's useful? I may be wrong, but always value your time.

A very intriguing hypothesis around the language instinct is covered in the book. However, it is a difficult read with few powerful insights explained with too much of unnecessary detail for the casual reader. Trust it could have been way shorter.

A really interesting book to read, particularly if you're interested in languages. It influenced how I speak to my kids–I now state the same thing in different ways (you're on the swing, I'm pushing you on the swing, you're swinging high) and often think back to this book.

Hard to believe a man as supposedly educated as Pinker was completely blind to the obvious fallacies of the theories presented in the book. On the upside, the idea of genetic grammar made for a good laugh

Pinker is a magnificent thinker. His way of proposing ideas shows you how knowledgeable he is. But showing how very complicated the language is and proposing that it came with evolution and liking it to elephant trunks is just bizarre argument I don't agree with.

This book opened my eyes to the multi-layered relationship between consciousness, biology, and language. I did find that Pinker tends to digress into academic minutia which made me lose track of the overarching narrative.

Fascinating, insightful, and easy to read. Spoiler alert: this book debunks entrenched beliefs about human nature, such as Orwell’s hypothesis that you could eliminate the idea of freedom by censoring the word itself (according to Pinker, you can’t; humans reinvent words when they go missing.)

What a great read. Steven examines language in a way that you can understand. He does so with a touch of humour throughout the book which makes it both pleasant as well as interesting.Highly recommended to anyone who is interested in linguistics and language..

It was amusing to read what appeared to be a raging Pinker in 'Language Mavens'. As an evolutionary biologist it's a must have. Was quite a tough read as an untalkative someone who still can't recollect what an infinitive is (even after first reading 'The Sense of Style') but happy I persevered.

Negative 3This is bay far the most coherently incoherent book that I have ever come across. Pinker aspires to be a figure like Chomsky in innovation and ends up with a nothing but superficial jokes about language and inconsequential explanations.
I love the idea and the learning, but it was pretty technical/heavy, so only read part of it. Would use as reference or read slowly
A great introduction to language and how it works
Fine book, except the parts where the author tries to defend English - for most of those were rather weak arguments that require little attempt to dismiss.
Perfect intro to linguistics, a discipline that is not what most people think it is!
Actually a very articulate and organized approach towards language and cognitive science. Liked the critique against the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis.
One of the best books i have ever read. Read this to aid my personal statement application for university 3 years ago!
Don’t know why I read blank slate before this. This was the best nonfiction book I’ve read in years.
A fascinating subject and one I am very much interested in.
I think there was one chapter, chapter 3 or 4, that was kind of a slog (explaining grammar, NPs, VPs, etc.). Very good book; I especially like the evolutionary biology tie-ins.
Interesting but too lonf
DNF. The first part was very interesting as it had several anecdotes about people but then it got very dry when it started going on about sentence structure and nouns and verbs and so on.
A little outdated at times and it felt a bit unfocused and lengthy at other times, but overall interesting read.
Oh how I could love to read an updated version of this!
